TALK.START.PARA: —I very much welcome the opportunity to speak this morning in support of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Bill. It is a very important Bill. In fact, it is perhaps the most important Bill for the future of Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australian relations. It is important at the outset to congratulate certainly the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Robert Tickner, and indeed the Opposition spokesperson, Dr Michael Wooldridge, on achieving bipartisan support. As honourable senators will know, it is unusual to get bipartisan support about many issues in either chamber of the Australian Parliament.
—Tripartisan.

—I beg Senator Kernot's pardon, but we take for granted on the question of Aboriginal rights the Democrats' support of a Bill such as this. It is significant that bipartisanship has been received, particularly when one considers some of the extremely negative debate that occurred when Minister Hand was putting forward the ATSIC legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Minister Tickner has worked strenuously to avoid the bitter and divisive debates of the past which have highlighted a polarisation of the major parties on how best to achieve social justice for the original Australians. This Bill, which will allow a 10-year process of conciliation and education, will, I believe, test Australia's reputation as an egalitarian society, because for all the rhetoric, for all the best efforts of government-certainly, both State and Federal governments have taken tremendous initiatives in the past and I commend them for their efforts-Australian Aborigines do not have equality in our society. This is being watched around the world. I do not think any member of this chamber has ever travelled overseas without being asked, `What about your Aborigines? What are you doing about the Aboriginal problem, as it is called?'.

This is not an Aboriginal problem; it is a white Australian problem. Certainly, the conditions that many Aboriginal Australians live in are a tremendous problem for them in that they cannot have the same standards of living as non-Aboriginal Australians. Nevertheless, it is important to emphasise that the problem rests with white Australians, and this reconciliation process is our last chance before the year 2001 to make a difference and to start to attain this vital goal. The Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody clearly identified the vital need for this reconciliation process. In its final report, chapter 38, recommendation 339, it stated:

That all political leaders and their parties recognize that reconciliation between the Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal communities in Australia must be achieved if community division, discord and injustice to Aboriginal people are to be avoided. To this end the Commission recommends that political leaders use their best endeavours to ensure bi-partisan public support for the process of reconciliation and that the urgency and necessity of the process be acknowledged.

Now we have that bipartisanship in this place and the House of Representatives, but I am concerned that it does not necessarily extend to all State parliaments. I urge all State governments to move in the same direction as the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the Hon. Robert Tickner, Dr Michael Wooldridge and the Australian Democrats have moved to get that bipartisanship in the Australian Parliament to ensure that it extends to other areas of government. It has not been achieved to date. Some of the statements that come out of the Queensland Parliament on behalf of the Liberal and National parties and a number of other State parliaments indicate that we still have a long way to go to get bipartisanship across all areas of government. Indeed, that could apply just as equally to local government, which has a special relationship with and a very important role to play in the Aboriginal reconciliation process.

Let me now turn my attention to one of the greatest tragedies affecting Aboriginal people; that is, Aboriginal deaths in custody and the very high rate of imprisonment of Aboriginal Australians. The Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody showed us that the statistics were extremely alarming and that the circumstances of the deaths in custody were deeply disturbing. Had the same rate of death in custody occurred among non-Aboriginal prisoners in Australia, it is estimated by the Australian Institute of Criminology that 7,592 deaths would have occurred in the eight-year period preceding the royal commission inquiry. I think that figure bears repeating: had the ratio of Aboriginal deaths been the same as for the rest of the population, 7,592 non-Aboriginal Australians would have died. This comparison highlights the scope of the tragedy of Aboriginal deaths in custody. It is inconceivable that 7,500 non-Aboriginal Australians could die in custody in unusual circumstances or that the situation could ever reach that level, and yet a comparable level, given the population basis of Aboriginal Australians, was accepted before the royal commission was held.

Furthermore, it is a strong reminder to us to tackle the crucial issue of Aboriginal criminal justice because, although we have the royal commission and it has brought down excellent reports with outstanding recommendations that must be adopted by governments, still the percentage of Aboriginal people in gaol rises. This is illustrated by a news report from yesterday that says that Australia's gaol population increased by 10 per cent in 1990, according to census figures released in Canberra yesterday. The Australian Institute of Criminology figures show that there were 14,304 prisoners in 1990 compared with 12,964 in 1989. However, a 40 per cent increase in Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders imprisoned was recorded in 1990, bringing the total to 2,041. Despite those appalling figures, the Royal Commission and the recommendations in the report brought down recently, still the imprisonment rate of Aboriginal people continues to escalate and to be totally distorted from the percentage increase of non-Aboriginal Australians.

Clearly, it is a responsibility for all governments to seriously tackle this problem. I will concede that State governments, particularly in my home State of Queensland, are starting to respond and some new initiatives have been taken. A unique Aboriginal and Islander prisoner committee has been set up in Townsville to liaise with prisoners and staff. However, while this committee is operating-and that is to be commended-management and staff continue to frustrate the efforts of that committee with petty detail that is totally inappropriate, given the scope of the problem that we have in relation to the rate of imprisonment and the rate of Aboriginal deaths in custody. For example, as recently as 12 April this year Aboriginal prisoners involved in an incident at the Townsville correctional centre were told by a correctional centre officer:
We don't have to hang you blacks. You black--
I am not going to say the word--
hang yourself.

That is a statement made in 1991. After all the talk, the Royal Commission and the efforts of Government, still, in a prison in this country, we have an officer who will make a statement like that. No wonder the Aboriginal and Islander prisoner liaison committee in Townsville is frustrated.

Yesterday, when I was preparing this speech, I got a note from one of the members of that liaison committee. He went out to the prison and was told by a senior member of management-after a meeting at the gate to the maximum security area-that he was not appropriately dressed to visit the centre. Since when were visits to prisoners a matter of high fashion? It is absolutely ludicrous that such a standard should be raised about the way in which a person was dressed. As the individual says:
I was better dressed than what I was when I addressed the UN in Geneva and also when I socialised with members of Royalty in Europe.

In the words of the Aboriginal member of the Aboriginal and Islander prisoners liaison committee, he was dressed in a similar fashion-in fact, he said that he was better dressed-to when he spoke at the United Nations. Yet that dress is not accepted when he is going in to work with prison staff to try to get better relations in the Townsville correctional centre. Clearly, the question of how we deal with this issue must be first on the agenda for the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation.

There are those who are not as effusive in their congratulations and their commitment to the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation. I want to speak for the remainder of my time about the concerns, the reservations and the outright objections that Aboriginal people have to the reconciliation process. I do not agree with them because I believe that this is such a unique opportunity for us to bring Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians together. If I were an Aboriginal person who had suffered the kinds of discrimination and frustration that they have for so many years, I would be cynical too. There have been so many words, so many promises and so much debate in the past that some Aboriginal people say, `Another talkfest-another opportunity for sitting around the table-but when will we get the fundamentals?'.

What are the fundamentals? A group of Aboriginal women from Queensland came to Canberra by bus yesterday to see me. I know that they spoke to Senator Kernot and the Minister. They are concerned because, firstly, they did not know about the reconciliation process until they arrived in Canberra yesterday. They had not heard about it.

That shows that, through ATSIC, we still have a long way to go to get that vital communication process in operation. We have ATSIC now, but ATSIC members have a vital responsibility to ensure that women like the women who visited me yesterday know what is going on, know about the programs and the commitments of government and know how the community has to be involved, because we will never get adequate reconciliation without the support of local communities, be they Aboriginal or non-Aboriginal. So communication and consultation are a priority.

These women were community leaders from Rockhampton and Brisbane. They are the people who have dealt with the alcoholism and the violence. They have inherited the memories of the rape by white settlers. They know that their sisters in Aurukun are trying to address the very serious disturbances in that community, and they say, `What will this reconciliation do for the health of our people? What will reconciliation do in terms of the education of our people? How will it stop the alcoholism?'. Above all, they say, `What about land rights? Until we have land rights and until we have economic independence to manage our own affairs, what will this reconciliation Bill do? We want basic justice. We don't want reconciliation'.

I think I managed to get the point through to the Government-this is the view that I believe in-that reconciliation is essential. With the exception of land rights, the Government is working on the issues of health, housing, education, employment and basic justice through legal aid for Aboriginal people. The question of land rights, however, is fundamental. I suppose that it is there where I draw a distinction between government policy and views that I hold about how important land rights is to this reconciliation process.

The long running academic debate about terra nullius has so far determined that Australian Aborigines have limited legality to land claims. However, the Mabo case, currently awaiting judgment in the High Court, could well challenge our traditional interpretation of Aboriginal settlement and subsequent policies for Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders.

In a recent article in the Age, Aboriginal lawyer Sandra Bailey remarked that Aborigines were still haunted by what she called the `empty land lie'. She explained that, as the head of the Aboriginal Issues Unit of the Victorian arm of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, she had held discussions with communities all over the State. In doing so, she had discovered that there was a broad consensus that the fundamental issue was that of dispossession. All other issues stem from it in some way. Seeking solutions to current Aboriginal problems, she had come to believe that an appropriate start would be the recognition of the sovereignty of Aboriginal people. It would remove the oppressive lie of terra nullius and take us out of dependency, which is perpetuating the cycle of poverty.

Of course, opponents of the Aboriginal cause would reject this prescription, while at the same time attaching great importance to the doctrine of terra nullius. Indeed, they would argue that it was adopted by the British Government when Australia was first settled, that it is now impossible to reverse such a decision and that any attempt to do so should be resisted because it could undermine the legal foundations of Australian society.

In this way, a rather obscure latin legal term, unknown to all but a few legal specialists until about 10 years ago, has become the focal point for the discussion of Aboriginal rights in contemporary Australia. The doctrine is still underpinned by traditional interpretation of both law and history. Each draws strength from the other.

In his 1971 judgment, Mr Justice Blackburn threw his full weight behind the doctrine. A major reason for this was his assessment of the reasons for the Imperial Government's rejection of the treaty negotiated between Victorian Aborigines and the entrepreneurial Port Phillip Association in 1835. The treaty, he argued, was never officially considered to be in the nature of the purchases from Indians which were customary in America. He said, `It was simply a trespass on Crown Land'. What is more, the action of the British authorities was `a cogent demonstration of the total absence from official policy of any idea that the Aboriginals had any proprietary interest in the land'.

That is a legal view but similarly, taking an historical view, in his An Australian Legal History, the legal historian, A.C. Castles, supported Blackburn's interpretation, arguing that the decision in the Batman affair `seems to have ended, once and for all, the possibility that Aboriginal rights should be recognised administratively, except when they were accorded by statute'. This interpretation has been reaffirmed recently by a number of academic historians. When the colonial government rejected Batman's treaty, Attwood explained, it reiterated the principles of terra nullius. Shaw concurred, arguing that by its action the British Government reiterated the orthodox view that Australia was uninhabited in 1778, that it was terra nullius.

The contentious doctrine still has powerful underpinning in history, but challenges have been mounted on both the legal and historical fronts. For example, recent research shows that the original intention of the British Government was far from clear and may in fact have been premised on the mistaken assumption that much of the continent was uninhabited and, therefore, literally terra nullius. Despite that, many early colonists-free settlers, missionaries, officials-recognised that Aborigines were in possession of land, of distinct and recognisable tracks of territory, which was defended against trespassers.

The Imperial Government made two distinct commitments to land rights between 1836 and 1848 in the letters patent granted to the South Australian Colonizing Commission and in the provisions for further rights on all land leased under the provisions of the Australian Waste Land Act 1848. Clearly, it remains open for debate in legal and historical circles. Of course, all these issues will come to a head in the Mabo case in which we expect a judgment to be brought down later this year.

Historic land rights legislation will be a crucial stepping stone in the reconciliation process in Queensland. We have to be fair and acknowledge that the legislation, while very strongly criticised by a number of Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people for failing to include a land acquisition fund-I cannot understand why Queensland could not adopt a similar practice to that adopted just across the border in New South Wales by a Liberal government-is an important start in acknowledging the legitimacy of the relationship of Aborigines with the land in Queensland.

However, I emphasise that in Queensland this legislation must only be regarded as a start and if there is not to be a land acquisition fund through the land tax procedure, which is a very simple, ongoing process, a land acquisition fund must be set up and funded generously through the Budgets of both the Queensland and Federal governments.

Queenslanders, like other Australians, will need to adopt a strong commitment to the reconciliation process. Queensland's history of race relations is not a proud one. The recent conflicts over land rights legislation indicate the sensitivity of the debate and the need for ongoing communication and understanding. Only through patient dialogue can we achieve genuine equity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the reasons why the Senate is able to debate the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Bill fairly thoroughly and with a deep understanding is that most honourable senators have the privilege of representing the whole of their State and, therefore, travel to many outback and remote areas. It is clear from the contribution from Senator Reynolds that she has spent a lot of time in the Queensland outback and has had that exposure. During my brief time in this place, I have had the privilege of going to places like Wyndham, Roebourne, Kalgoorlie, Norseman and Carnarvon where there are significant Aboriginal populations and significant problems within the Aboriginal communities.

SPEECH.PARA: In trying to solve the problems of the Aboriginal community and reconcile the non-Aboriginal and Aboriginal communities, there has been a preoccupation with structures, bureaucracy and government imposed solutions. The latter part of Senator Reynolds's contribution on the land rights debate highlighted that preoccupation.

The land rights debate in my home State of Western Australia took place in the early 1980s. Brian Burke became Premier, having solemnly promised the people of Western Australia land rights in the lead-up to the election. That promise led to an unnecessarily divisive debate which did more to hurt the chances of any reconciliation between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people than anything else that has happened in Western Australia for a long, long time.

Indeed, one could argue that the infamous Noonkanbah dispute was less harmful to the reconciliation process than the land rights debate which was sparked by the then Premier, Brian Burke. The former Premier built up to an unsustainable level people's hopes in both communities. Of course, when he backed off his land rights promise, he upset the Aboriginal community and those people in the non-Aboriginal community who supported those land rights claims. As a result, he hurt relations between Aboriginals and non-Aboriginals.

So we must be careful-and all people contributing to this debate have recognised this fact-not to raise people's hopes too much through the creation of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation. All honourable senators contributing to the debate have been careful to point that out. I do not think any of us are creating expectations that are too high.

Senator Reynolds pointed out that the delegation that saw her and other honourable senators yesterday did not know about the reconciliation process. This reinforces the need for all of us to work to ensure that the Council is not just another bureaucracy, council, committee, summit or talk-feast. It has to get back to the local community. There has to be activity at the community level and political will behind the process to ensure that this reconciliation is implemented.

There have been communication and negotiations between the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner) and the shadow Minister, Dr Wooldridge, to ensure that the structure being set up is accountable. There need to be targets and mission statements. It is important that performance be judged on a regular basis by this Parliament and the community. This should help to solve problems in a way that previous councils have been unable to do.

Some of the disputes that have occurred around Australia in the past few months include: Coronation Hill; the ongoing disputes in Western Australia over the Wagyl; the Swan Brewery site; the preoccupation with sacred sites; and now the Yakabindie dispute where the Premier, Carmen Lawrence, wants to proceed with the development of that nickel deposit by Dominion Mining. Her Minister for Aboriginal Affairs is now calling for a fourth ethnographic survey of the area after three have been completed and after the local Aboriginal communities have clearly said that they want to proceed with the development. Of course, other Aboriginal groups thousands of miles away from the Yakabindie area are trying to stop the development. They are now calling for the Federal Minister, Robert Tickner, to intervene and stop the development of this nickel deposit.

This is simply a good example-or a bad example, one might say-of the sort of division that is caused between the Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal communities. It is not the fault of the local Aboriginals around the Yakabindie area. It is the fault of the political activists who would seek to use the Aboriginal cause, the heritage values associated with sacred sites, and the religious beliefs, for their own political ends. If the reconciliation process can focus upon this harmful aspect and the way that the Aboriginal cause is used as a pawn in a political game, perhaps we can achieve something.

There has been a multi-partisan commitment, a humanitarian commitment, by politicians of all parties over the past few decades to solving the problems with which the Aboriginal race are afflicted. On any reflection it is fair to say that the humanitarian commitment, the concern which has been reflected in the millions and probably billions of dollars which have gone towards the solution of those Aboriginal problems, has done little to help the cause of the Aboriginal people over the last two or three decades.

If one goes to places such as Wyndham, Roebourne, Kalgoorlie, Norseman or Carnarvon, one sees that the plight of the Aboriginal people in many of those areas-in the towns, on the fringes of the towns and out on some of the stations and missions-is a very sad and sorry sight. It has not improved with the expenditure of all those millions and indeed billions of dollars over the past three decades. Let us all hope that this reconciliation process means there is at least some sort of light at the end of the tunnel. It will create a little more hope and may help to solve some of the problems.

The Opposition's support for this legislation is based on the fact that reconciliation needs to be achieved at the community level. It is no use setting up another bureaucracy in Canberra to solve these problems; we have proved in the past that that does not work. We must concentrate on Aboriginal criminal justice, the crime rate among the Aboriginal community, the mortality rate, health problems, and the destruction of much of the heritage and rich culture of the Aboriginal people. We must create a process that ensures that non-Aboriginal Australians have a deeper understanding of the Aboriginal race, their opportunities and their problems.

The `us and them' mentality which has grown up in many of the towns in Western Australia is something that needs to be solved. I have somewhat cynical reservations about what this process can achieve, but the `us and them' mentality, which is clearly evident in some of the towns I have mentioned, is one of the problems that needs to be solved. When one walks down the main street of a town such as Roebourne and sees Aborigines lying down along the median strips with bottles of wine and beer lying around them, one wonders at the depth of the problem and what this reconciliation process can do to alleviate that.

One of the concerns that I have with this legislation is that coming up with a treaty or some instrument of reconciliation could be seen in the long run as the only practical or solid evidence of any achievement, and that could become the sole focus of this Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation. In Dr Hewson's letter to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on this subject earlier this year, he said:

We fully support the statement of Commissioner Johnston, contained in his final report into the Aboriginal Deaths in Custody where he said: ``The approach should concentrate on the process of reconciliation and not on an instrument . . .

I support that process. It is quite clear from the clauses of the Bill creating this Council that there is a concentration on producing a formal document or documents. Indeed, in subclause 6(1) under the functions of the Council there is quite a preoccupation with the outcome of a document. Paragraphs (g) and (h) read:
(g) to consult Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders and the wider Australian community on whether reconciliation would be advanced by a formal document or formal documents of reconciliation; and

(h) after that consultation, to report to the Minister on the views of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders and the wider Australian community as to whether such a document or documents would benefit the Australian community as a whole and if the Council considers there would be such a benefit, to make recommendations to the Minister on the nature and content of, and manner giving effect to, such a document or documents . . .
Out of all the functions of the Council, that is probably the most specific reference to any action which will actually take place under this reconciliation process.

I restate my concern that treaties, structures and bureaucracies will not solve these problems. If, in the end, this Council for Reconciliation focuses on the creation of a treaty or even on building up a political ground swell for a treaty then, in my eyes, it will have failed because that is not going to solve the problems this nation is faced with. Until we solve those problems that in the last decade we have not been able to solve, we cannot ever call ourselves a mature nation because in the eyes of the world and in our own eyes the plight of the Aboriginal people is a plight of all Australian people. It is a problem for all of us.

I conclude by referring to comments made by Senator Reynolds and other honourable senators in this debate. It is important to have a genuine, multipartisan approach to this issue. Nothing can be achieved in this important area of activity without a genuine commitment by all parties. That commitment needs to be across all of the State parliaments, at the local government level, at the local community level and, most importantly, here in Federal Parliament. We have achieved that more and more over previous years, particularly in the last 12 or 15 months with the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and the shadow Minister, Dr Wooldridge.

If we go down the track of trying to create a treaty, of building up a political ground swell for a treaty or using the reconciliation process to put national land rights back onto the political agenda, then that non-partisanship will disappear very quickly. I caution honourable senators to ensure that this reconciliation process does focus on activity and reconciliation at the community level and that it does not, as a consequence, seek to place a treaty and land rights back on the national political agenda. That would destroy that bipartisanship and any hope that this Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation will create in the minds of all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I will not detain the Senate long in responding to the contributions that have been made during this debate. In the main, they have been thoughtful and positive. Most speakers have stressed at least conditional support for the beginning of this process. I would like to comment on the reference made by Senator Campbell to the Opposition amendments that are going to be moved at the conclusion of this debate in respect of setting up benchmarks and targets to be met by this Council.

SPEECH.PARA: I simply indicate at this stage that the Government will be opposing these amendments. My own personal view is that they are not amendments that anyone would want to die in a ditch over on either side of the Parliament. They are largely peripheral issues but, in my view, they do relate to a very important point.

Senator Campbell did place great emphasis on the need for this Council to achieve benchmarks and targets. In the contribution to this debate made by my colleague from the Northern Territory, Senator Tambling, he referred to something in similar vein in respect of accountability and responsibility in the allocation of funding. It is reasonable to say that honourable senators should take note of contributions which are made to debates such as this by people like Senator Tambling, who represents such a very high proportion of Aboriginal people in the electorate he serves.

I must say, with respect, that this relates to something which irritates me greatly. In past debates in this chamber I have said that Aboriginal people in Australia, with regard to achieving the targets that we set for them, are in the same position as women in the community in that it is never good enough for them to do as well as everyone else for them to be seen equally with everyone else; they always have to do better than everyone else. In his contribution Senator Tambling said:

Over the past four years I have asked thousands of questions in the Federal Parliament and in Senate Estimates committees relating to the waste and inefficiency in the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio. I make no apologies; my motives in concentrating on this portfolio were and are to improve the efficiency of service delivery, to demand accountability for taxpayers' funds . . .

They are goals which I support and with which I agree. Accountability does need to be brought in but it also needs to be put into perspective in terms of the constant emphasis which is placed on the failure of Aboriginal people and Aboriginal communities to meet these targets and benchmarks that we set.

By comparison, who are some of the premier people in our community-in our society-at the upper end of the social scale? I would suggest that they are people in the corporate sector and in the banking industry. These are people who are held in high regard and are considered to be some of the more responsible, and they are certainly well-off citizens in this country. I want to put this in context. I am not saying I am decrying the need for this accountability; it is essential for every single dollar of taxpayers' money that is spent.

It is fair to note that in terms of this upper echelon of our own society which we hold in such high regard, the corporate sector and the banking sector in the Australian community in the last four to five years have flushed down the toilet, not money that has been wasted on Aboriginal Affairs, but more money-if we added up every single dollar since Federation-than has ever been spent on the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio in total by every conceivable government.

This is not a partisan view-I think many people in the Opposition would share it. There does seem to be a different standard that we as a community apply to the multi billions of dollars thrown away by the outrageous behaviour of the corporate sector-linked to some fairly irresponsible behaviour, in my view, by the banking sector in supporting it-in the last four to five years, when compared with the money spent on citizens who, beyond argument, are still the most deprived people in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —And a couple of State governments to boot.

—I agree with Senator Campbell. Absolutely. I was simply lumping them in with this entire unfortunate four or five years that we have had in Australian history, which I think has been unparalleled. Hopefully, we have all learned lessons from it so that we never see it again.

SPEECH.PARA: To be fair to Senator Tambling-and I want to be fair to Senator Tambling-I did try to follow this debate and I read the speeches of those speakers I could not follow. Unfortunately, I was tied up when Senator Tambling spoke, but I read his speech this morning and, to be fair, he did start off on this negative note for the first eight or nine pages. It is worthy of note that he did then say:

The opposite side of the coin is to look at the positive areas where results are evident. I put on the record a couple of points that need to be recognised. One is public education and the other is public health.

Senator Tambling made two positive suggestions in the areas of public education and public health, as anyone who reads his speech will note. Frankly, these suggestions intrigued me. I look forward with anticipation to the contributions that will be made in the deliberations of this Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Bill as to the suggestions of people who are familiar with the Aboriginal community and how Aboriginal people can improve their lot.
One of Senator Tambling's positive suggestions was that Aboriginal people should spend far more time watching the Bill Cosby program on television. I am not misquoting him. This is what he said:
I recount a recent visit that I made to Ngukurr, a community in my electorate, where I sat down with elders of the council . . .

Senator Tambling said that one of the elders said that he liked watching the Bill Cosby program. When Senator Tambling asked him why, he said `that for the first time he had seen what it was like inside my lounge room'-that is, Senator Tambling's lounge room-`my bedroom, my kitchen, and how I managed my relationships with my teenage kids'. I have great difficulty in accepting that this is what did happen, but Senator Tambling said it did, so I assume it did. Senator Tambling went on to say:
I believe that appreciation comes from the fact that usually an Aboriginal person would not get into my house in a normal operational way-

I assume that means through the front door. I cannot understand what other meaning could be put on it. `An Aboriginal person would not get into my house in a normal operational way'-I think that is extraordinary language. He continued:

. . . I would rather see a television set put into every Aboriginal humpy before a water tap . . . A number of people felt that I was being heartless and cruel in not putting in the essential water tap first.

He was referring to the statement he made in the Northern Territory. I would like to dissociate myself from those people who thought that Senator Tambling was being heartless and cruel by suggesting that Aboriginal people needed a colour television before they needed fresh water. I did not think that at all. I just thought Senator Tambling was being ignorant.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did I say in the next paragraph?
—In the next paragraph Senator Tambling suggested what should be done to improve Aboriginal health; that is to say that Aboriginal communities should have a mattress replacement program.
—No, the bit about the water tap-the education that would follow.
—Regarding the water tap, Senator Tambling said:

SPEECH.PARA: But I was really saying that if we would put in a means of communication, the water tap would soon follow and it would be used properly in the administration of health.

Senator Tambling was saying that if we put a colour television set in every Aboriginal `humpy' in the Northern Territory-and I recall the statement when he made it; I thought it was absurd then, I think it is absurd now, and I am astonished that he would give it breath in the Federal Parliament-the Aboriginal people would have the opportunity to watch the Bill Cosby program on television and would learn how to responsibly use the water taps which we would then benevolently give them.

In terms of allocating public funds, I personally would prefer to see them spent initially on water and sewerage facilities rather than on putting television sets in every Aboriginal humpy so that Aboriginal people could learn the benefits of our good life by watching Bill Cosby on television. But, to be fair to Senator Tambling, he went on to make another positive contribution. He said that there should be a mattress replacement program in Aboriginal communities. So it will be an interesting debate. As soon as we fix Aboriginal people, as soon as those Aboriginal people are in the happy position of being able to sit in their humpy on their new mattress, watching Bill Cosby on their 25-inch colour television, everything else will follow.

Senator Tambling is entitled to his views. I do not think there is any debate in this Parliament that will canvass a more broad-ranging and divergent set of views than Aboriginal affairs. It has in all the debates that I have read-in the Hansards of not only the Federal Parliament but also the State parliaments. I have a particular view on how government should approach Aboriginal people which I know is not universally popular with some Aboriginal people. Senator Tambling probably would not disagree with it too much.

I guess we are all entitled to see people as we like to. Some people look at people and see them as black, yellow or brown; Moslem, Catholic or Protestant. I suppose that after a long time in public administration, in trying to do my poor best to help people who walk into my office, as Senator Tambling does, I see people in two groups-those who need help and those who do not.

I make that point because Senator Crowley, in her contribution to this debate, said that she felt it was wrong for people to reiterate constantly the sins of the past and concentrate on the injustices of the past in the attitudes we take towards improving the lot of Aboriginal people. I agree with her. The simple point I make is that when addressing the injustices done to Aboriginal people there is absolutely no need to live in the past. I think we need to be conscious of the past; I think we need to be aware of the truth of what happened and why it happened and we need to be aware of to what very great degree government policies were directly instrumental in bringing about some of those injustices. But in terms of trying to redress the injustice done to Aboriginal people, there is simply no need to live in the past. All we have to do is live in the present.

I know what the present realities are for Aboriginal people in terms of my own life. I know that because my wife spends most of her free time doing three things: visiting relatives or friends in gaol-that is hardly surprising considering that in excess of 80 per cent of the prison population in the Northern Territory is black-visiting friends and relatives in hospital; and going to funerals. That is what she does most and I do a fair bit of it myself. That is the reality of life for most Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory today.

I recently visited Batchelor College and talked to a friend of mine, David McLeay, who is the Assistant Principal at the College-whom I am sure Senator Tambling knows-about our dreadful personal agony at watching the destruction of Aboriginal communities by substance abuse. I say `substance abuse' not alcohol abuse, because these days kava is wreaking as much havoc among my friends as alcohol is-worse in some cases. David spent many years at Millingimbi and I had just come back from there. I told him about some of the things I had seen and the real shock and distress I had felt at seeing my friends. A particular friend-a teacher at the school who had taught under David-whom I had not seen for some five years is in his early forties and looks like a man of 95, courtesy of kava.

I ask the Senate to forgive me for telling these anecdotal stories, but they are simply an indication of real life today in an Aboriginal community. I recounted this story to David and he told me of a mutual friend of ours-I do not want to name him as I have not spoken to him about this-who works as an Aboriginal lecturer at the college. David said that a young Aboriginal man from Batchelor died last week from an alcohol-related accident. He said that he had gone to this person at the college and said, `Look, we've got to do something about arranging the funeral for so and so'. He said what followed was quite extraordinary. This person whom he named, off the top of his head, gave him the telephone number of the undertaker in Darwin and the name of the person whom David had to contact at the funeral director's office. In five minutes he reeled off precisely the arrangements that David had to make, including which person he needed to talk to from the air charter company and that person's telephone number. The point is that this particular individual had had to organise so many funerals that this was normal daily business for him. These are tragic human problems that have to be addressed.

My view is that, despite all the agonising that has been done by blacks and whites over the terrible injustices that are inflicted, particularly on the real victims of much of this debate-that is the Aboriginal women and children from these communities-one does not have to be a Rhodes scholar to work out fundamentally why it happens. It happens because people are profoundly unhappy.

I recall from my youth-and these things stick in one's head-something that my old grandmother used to say to me. My old grandmother was probably like the old grandmothers of many people in here-the backbone of the nation types, wonderful ladies, the sustainers of their families for many years and so on. There used to be many of those people about the place, and they were mostly women. My grandmother used to tell me as a kid that people need three things in this world to be happy: something to do, something to hope for and someone to love. There is still an enormous amount of truth in that view.

I suppose that happiness for me, being a total depressive, is when I am not actively suicidal. So it is all relative. When I apply those three fundamental requirements for happiness to Aboriginal friends of mine, it is not hard to see why they turn to booze, kava and everything else. One does not have to tell Aboriginal people what their real place in this society is-they know. In vino veritas, one only has to sit down and have a yarn with them at 3 o'clock in the morning when they are drunk for many of their opinions to come out.

Aboriginal people are well aware of the position they really hold in society, and it is a pretty depressing reality if people try to put themselves in their shoes. As I have said on many occasions in the past, it is not hard. If I was a young Aboriginal person with no job, no prospect of having one, with probably a marginal grasp of my language and culture and very little prospect of anything else happening to improve that, I would probably be hard put to stay off the booze myself. So there is a real need-and we all agree on this-to practically attempt to address, within the real limitations that governments of any political persuasion have, the social injustices so that we can help to provide Aboriginal people with something to do and something to hope for.

I am encouraged by the contributions made to this debate. I believe that the sentiments expressed by Opposition speakers in this debate are genuine. I believe that we all hope something positive will come out of this process in cooperation with the Aboriginal community. However, having regard to some of the cautions that have quite rightly been expressed by Opposition as well as Government speakers, I want to conclude on this note: at the end of the day we do live in a parliamentary democracy. For many of us, including myself-and pugnacious people like Senator Baume would probably be in the same position-it is often very frustrating to live within the real limitations of a parliamentary democracy. At the end of the day the majority rules. Quite often, people find themselves being passionately committed to causes and issues about which they have deep feelings but are defeated. It happens to us all every time.

TALK.START.PARA: —It happens to us more than others.

—It happens to the Australian Democrats statistically more than anyone else. In a long period of public life, it is difficult to learn to live with those limitations and still be prepared to say, `Look, even though I got done like a dinner and I hate it, the process itself is worth going on with'. That is particularly difficult for Aboriginal people, who are in a substantial minority in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that what I am about to say will not go down very well with many Aboriginal people whom I know; they will disagree with me. But the difficulty for us all in this process is that we do live in a democracy with all its limitations. A close friend of mine, Father Frank Brennan, who I think is one of the more lucid thinkers in the white community on these issues and whom I have known for many years and have had many hours of discussion with, put in writing his own views-for what they are worth-to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs on what he saw as being the reasonable limitations that exist in any process. He did not just talk about treaties or instruments of reconciliation, but everything else.

I do not have his letter in front of me, but I think that I am doing him reasonable justice when I paraphrase it, and I hope accurately enough-when he laid these points down it struck a chord with me because I agree with him-by saying that what has to be determined in any process is, firstly, what Aboriginal people want. Only one group in the community can legitimately participate in that debate, and that is the Aboriginal people. As Senator Tambling knows full well, what one Aboriginal community wants is often dramatically and radically different from what another wants. Indeed, what often happens-and the Coronation Hill debate of recent times demonstrated this very effectively-is that there are as many disagreements about issues in an Aboriginal community as there are in the non-Aboriginal community. Nevertheless, only the Aboriginal community can initially determine what Aboriginal people want.

Having done that and determined to put it into effect, a judgment then has to be made whether what they want is morally reasonable and justifiable. In my view, as in Frank Brennan's view, it is not just the Aboriginal community that is entitled to participate in that debate. Aboriginal people do not have an absolute ownership of morality. We are all entitled to make our own judgments about what is morally justifiable and reasonable in a democracy, as painful as some of them might be, and to canvass them publicly. Having determined that, what then has to be determined is whether it is politically achievable, because that in reality is what will occur at the end of the process.

There may well be many Aboriginal people, if they acknowledge that that is the process we have to adopt-and in my view it is-who might say in respect of things, for example, like sovereignty, over which many Aboriginal people legitimately have strong views, `Look, in our view, if that is the test that has to be applied'-and I think it is-`ceding sovereignty to Aboriginal people not being politically achievable', and in my view it is not, `this is a process in which we will not participate because we will never be satisfied with the end result'.

If this is to be an honest debate, I honestly believe that all the participants in it, both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal, do need to apply those three tests. It may well be that when applying those three tests many non-Aboriginal people will feel that this is a debate that they do not want to participate in, either. That is a judgment they have to make. Hopefully, at the end of the day the result will be as encouraging and as positive as having the first step of this process set up. All of us-that is, the Aboriginal community and, in particular, the people who at the end of the day have to deliver something, the members of this Federal Parliament and our colleagues in the State parliaments-will deliver something that is meaningful so that the exercise is considered worth while. In conclusion, I simply say again that I thank all honourable senators for their contributions to the debate. I look forward to support on both sides of the Federal Parliament for the successful conclusion of this enterprise.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Clause 6, page 4, line 9, at the end of subclause (1) add the following word and paragraph:
``and (k) to monitor and evaluate:
(i) the implementation of benchmarks in relation to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander well-being, as agreed by Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments; and
(ii) the progress towards achieving those benchmarks.
2. Clause 19, page 10, omit subclauses (2) to (5), substitute the following subclause:
``(2) A person to whom this section applies is to be reimbursed the expenses that the person reasonably incurs in performing duties under this Act.''.
3. Clause 19, page 10, subclause (6), line 38, after ``subsection'', omit ``(5)'', substitute ``(2)''.
4. Clause 19, pages 10 and 11, line 39 (page 10), to line 24 (page 11), omit subclauses (7) to (9).

The thrust of these amendments is to seek to amend the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Bill in two ways. In the first place, the amendments seek to set benchmarks so that we can measure the success or otherwise of this venture. I dealt with this at some length in my speech during the second reading debate. I do not want to canvass the matter again beyond saying that we are strongly of the view that there has not been enough concentration on the issue in the past by previous governments about whether what we have been doing for the Aboriginal people, in conjunction with the Aboriginal people, has at the bottom line been in their best interests, and whether we have had successes or failures. Many people are of the view that the net outcome has been one of failure.

Listening to the concerns that Senator Collins has about the problems of alcohol and other forms of abuse, one sees the need not only for this Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation but also for the measurement of our success or otherwise because, clearly, there are indications of a degree of failure in the past. We are not here to apportion blame, nor are we here to criticise each other.

I must say that I was a little disappointed by Senator Collins's comments which misinterpreted what Senator Tambling said. I was disappointed that Senator Collins had to be pushed to read Senator Tambling's next sentence which demonstrated why Senator Tambling had made the fairly dramatic statement that in some instances improved information to the Aboriginal people could lead to a greater capacity to welcome and use effectively, in a health sense, various facilities. I hope that maybe, on reflection, Senator Collins will recognise that the thrust of this debate has been multipartisan, if I can use that word in order to acknowledge the Australian Democrats' position as well. I certainly want to maintain that atmosphere in the debate.

I hope that there will be a recognition of the need for some benchmarks, even though this will not be in the legislation. I am certain that the Government will have the same sort of enthusiasm to make certain that this legislation works and is in the best interests of all Aboriginal people. I hope that there will be de facto benchmarks and de facto measures of success even if they are not de jure in the Act.

The second amendment that I have moved relates to the question of fees to members of the Council. I was interested to hear Senator Collins say, `Well, really, these amendments are peripheral'. He said that, basically, one would not die in the ditch over them. It is true the Opposition is not going to die in the ditch over them. But we still think they are significant; we still think they are matters of principle. We are not dying in the ditch over them because we do not want any suggestion of division to emerge in this multipartisan approach to the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation. That is the reason we are not pressing the amendments.

However, as a matter of principle, we think it is wrong that payment should be made to members of the Council. Senator Collins knows only too well that the Government's original draft maintained the position that we are now maintaining. I do not want to push the Government or the Minister. My understanding is that perhaps the Minister has had difficulties in maintaining what I understood to be his preferred position-which is a polite way of putting it.

I simply want to stress that our decision not to divide on this amendment-although we have moved it-does not diminish in any way our belief that it is right, that it puts forward a principle and that it would improve the workings of the Council. As I said in the second reading debate, we do not want to see this as simply another `jobs for the boys or girls'. Our concern is that such an atmospheric could tarnish the Council.

I hope that that risk will not be faced. I trust that the calibre and quality of the people appointed will remove any suggestions that `jobs for the boys or girls' will be an element in the membership of the Council. But it seems to me that this is an unnecessary risk to run on such an important issue; it is an unnecessary risk to let this Council be subject to the prospect of such criticism. It is only because of our deep concern and hopes for the success of this Council that we have moved the amendments. I commend them to the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, through you, I would like to ask Senator Baume a question about amendment No. 1, which actually uses the words:

SPEECH.PARA: the implementation of benchmarks in relation to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander well-being . . .

While I understand what the Opposition is saying about the accountability, I would like to hear from Senator Baume some suggestions about how we are going to measure. What are the benchmarks of well-being? It is not a three-bedroom brick home; it is not an absence of tooth decay; and it is not tertiary degrees. Is it poverty line statistics? Is it imprisonment rate? What is it and how do you measure it? I see this as one of the difficulties with the amendment.

Secondly, in the preamble of the Bill we have an indication that an essential part of the reconciliation process is the need to address the disadvantage of Aboriginal and Islander people. On behalf of the Democrats, I am happy to accept the explanation in the preamble that this Council is being established as a way of monitoring the implementation of whatever processes we decide upon, in consultation, and measuring the progress being made. I do not think it is a legitimate function of the Council to attempt to monitor in this way the concept of well-being. I await with interest Senator Baume's explanation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Council must develop, and prepare in writing, strategic plans in accordance with this section.

Apparently we can have a strategy without in fact having a way of measuring the success of the programs. As I understand it, that is the difference between the situation outlined in the Bill and the situation that we are presenting. It seems to me great to have a strategy--

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you do it? It is a very difficult concept.

—I concede the point that it is a very difficult concept. This is a very difficult area-it is an area in which we have continually failed. It seems to me that, unless someone applies his mind to what are the benchmarks, we are not going to achieve anything.
—Don't you know how you think it can be done?

—This is the whole problem. I am interested to hear the comment from the honourable senator. We are not prejudging what the benchmarks should be. We are saying that the Council must establish some. I am afraid that we are not-I will not say sufficiently arrogant, but that is probably what it is-sufficiently prepared to prejudge the matter to say what we believe the Council should set as its benchmarks. We think it is up to the Council to establish some benchmarks against which its performance can be measured. If its performance cannot be measured, if it is incapable of establishing whether at the bottom line the net result is of net benefit to the Aboriginal people, we are all wasting our time again. I say `again' because in a large volume of our legislation and intervention in Aboriginal affairs we have in fact `wasted our time' and destroyed the lives of large numbers of Aboriginal people. The alcohol abuse, for example, did not emerge from on high; it emerged as a result of deliberate policies determined by the white Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems unreal to me that we will be setting out on a course which seeks to achieve reconciliation, and are setting strategies to do it, but are not requiring the Council to establish whether or not those strategies have worked, what the results of the strategies have been, and whether or not we are achieving what is in the best interests of the Aboriginal people.

Quite frankly, I assume that there will be, as I said, de facto benchmarks there. All we were seeking to do was to require them to be there and to avoid a situation in which a council which might be less enthusiastic than I hope it will be might seek to fudge the issue. I do not expect a good council to fudge it. I hope that there will be benchmarks. I hope that the very problems that have been raised will be properly coped with by the Council. All we were seeking to do was to put into the legislation what we think will actually happen anyway.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendment moved by Senator Baume, which would require the Council to have benchmarks by which it would measure its performance. There is a very simple reason for doing this, Mr Chairman-and you would appreciate this-we cannot have a good government without a good opposition. This Government has a very good Opposition, as Senator Chapman says. Unfortunately, the Opposition sometimes exceeds the Government. The role of an opposition is to keep a government up to its task. The role of an opposition is to ensure that a government performs adequately.

SPEECH.PARA: Now, unfortunately, in the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Bill we have no measure by which the Council, which all of us in this chamber support, can be kept to its task. It is inappropriate, if we are to have a Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, to have an opposition to that Council. That would defeat the purpose. I am sure that everybody in this chamber would agree with that but, because we cannot have an opposition to ensure that the Council meets the criteria set out for it, that it actually performs its task, it is necessary to find some other mechanism by which the success of the Council can be measured, by which we can judge whether it is really doing what we are hoping it will do.

For that reason, we believe that it is very important that the Bill when it is passed have within it a requirement to set benchmarks. Otherwise we will have a Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation that will not be able to be measured, we will not know the success of the efforts of the Council and there will be no method by which the Council can be kept firmly glued to its task. For these reasons, those of us on this side strongly support the amendments moved by Senator Baume. What we must do is not just set up a Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation but put in place a framework by which that reconciliation process can be made effective.

A comment that is quite frequently made to me by members of the Aboriginal community is simply that they have ATSIC, but that ATSIC again is a structure without an opposition, and a structure without any benchmarks by which performance is indicated. They say that this leads in certain circumstances to some of the ATSIC councils and forums not being properly kept to the task. Aboriginal people say to me that this is a source of some dissatisfaction for them. We are embarking upon a landmark effort to solve or alleviate the Aboriginal problem. It is appropriate, therefore, that we get it right the first time. Therefore, I believe it is critical that we have in place methods to ensure that the Council continues to perform to the high standard which we all hope and expect it will deliver, but we need to be able to measure the performance.

Senator Kernot would be well aware of the incredibly successful efforts of former Senator Peter Baume in Estimates committees. Senator Peter Baume introduced into the Estimates committee process the idea of performance parameters. Everybody in this chamber knows how he did it. He would turn up at an Estimates committee hearing for a random department and say to the departmental officers, `What are your performance parameters? What are your performance indicators? How do you know you have been successful?'. Without wishing to single out any of Peter Baume's achievements as more significant than others, let me say that I think that was a very significant achievement, because it started to bring accountability and a thorough management process into the way the Senate Estimates committees scrutinise the expenditure and the operations of government departments. But we do not want to have to have another Peter Baume to knock the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation for six, 12 or 18 months and say, `What are your performance indicators?'. We all accept in this chamber now that performance indicators are absolutely essential to good management, so let us now embrace the idea of benchmarks-which is another word for performance indicators-in this Bill to ensure that we get it right the first time.

This chamber has a great Estimates committee process. It does really great things. We need to take our proven success in that area and apply it to this field so that the process for Aboriginal reconciliation does not go down the wrong road. How are we going to set those benchmarks? That was the other question that Senator Kernot put to Senator Michael Baume. I want to address that matter, too. I am not trying to fudge the issue. In part, the matter has to be determined by the Council, but we have to require the Council to make very clear what those benchmarks are. The actual goal setting, of course, is part of the process of reconciliation, and the benchmarks for the success of the Council will come out of the process of goal setting. The way I would envisage this whole scheme working is that the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation would sit down and decide what goals it ultimately wanted to achieve. Some of those goals will perhaps be unattainable, but they will be goals that are worth striving for anyway.

Having set those goals, it is then appropriate and possible to set benchmarks along the way by which the Council can determine whether it has been successful and by which it can reassess the process to ensure that it manages to perform to the optimal level. We do not want to have any possibility that, for whatever reason, this process could get sidetracked. That is why we believe that it is important that the Bill contain right at the outset a requirement for benchmarks.

This would achieve one other very important objective. One of the great problems with what was formerly the Department of Aboriginal Affairs-now the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission-is that people say too frequently that Aboriginal Affairs is not accountable and is not subject to the rules of accountability, whether that be financial accountability or accountability in terms of the performance that the service delivers. This is not a criticism that comes just from the wider white community, but frequently it comes to me from members of the Aboriginal community because they say that too often the structures set up to deal with the Aboriginal problems are not accountable to the people and there is no real way to work out their effectiveness.

By supporting this amendment we have an opportunity to do away with that potential objection to the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation. That is why I believe we have to embrace this amendment, because it would put up front the fact that it is not just a new era of talkfest but a new era of attitude to Aboriginal reconciliation, and that the Council will be started off on the right foot.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you measure that?

—Senator Kernot is still asking how we measure attitude. That is a very good question; in part, it is a very difficult process. Opinion polls are part, but not all, of it, because we all know how inaccurate opinion polls are. However, we have to put a requirement that this be done. Part of it will be opinion polls, but part of it will be other things as well; for example, we can encourage the Aboriginal community to raise its self-esteem within the wider community through its own achievements.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, the ultimate goal setting is the first task of the Council. What Senator Baume and I are saying is that, having set those goals, the Council must set benchmarks so that everybody can see that the process is more than a talkfest. We want this to work; we have one chance; we should not blow it now and that is why we must support the amendment moved by Senator Baume.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just wanted to let Senator O'Chee, who may not have seen the Bill, know that under Part 3, Strategic Plans, clause 10(4) reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Each strategic plan must set out, for each financial year . . .
It goes on with subclauses (4) (a), (b) and (c), sets out the goals and objectives, and clause 10(4) (d) reads:
such performance indicators and targets as the Council considers appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Stop pinching my lines!
—Oh, I am sorry, Minister; I happen to know what is in the Bill as well. Senator O'Chee will have an opportunity to comment on these performance indicators because the Minister:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . is to cause a copy of each strategic plan to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after approval by the Minister of the plan.

I believe that everything that we have been saying will be taken care of. The Council is to set goals, performance indicators and targets, and we will have an opportunity to look at them and comment on them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Kernot for that contribution because it prompted a response from the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) that she was stealing his lines. That cheers me up because the Minister may have closed the debate without recognising how inadequate that reply would have been.

SPEECH.PARA: Were Senator Kernot to turn to Part 2, clause 6(1) (j), she would note that:

in accordance with Part 3, to develop strategic plans that include a statement of the Council's goals and objectives in the promotion of the process of reconciliation and of its strategies for achieving them, together with indicators and targets for measuring the Council's performance in relation to those goals and objectives.

However, the Council is to provide indicators and targets for measuring, but the Council itself is not required to measure. That is the issue; I thought that was clear enough. Our amendment would require the Council to monitor and evaluate itself. Surely Senator Kernot realises that that is a significant difference? That is the reason the Opposition is moving this amendment; the Opposition is saying that the Council must monitor and evaluate the implementation of benchmarks in relation to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander well-being and, of course, then-not simply, as indicated, by one group, but by Commonwealth, State and Territory governments-progress towards achieving those benchmarks. That goes much further than clause 6(1) (i) of Part 2, which says:
to report, in the Council's annual report, on progress towards reconciliation . . .

Through that clause the Council does not have to establish what the benchmarks of progress are and it does not have to monitor or evaluate them itself. We are calling on the Council to do that; we think this is a gap in the legislation and, as I said earlier, I am convinced the Council will do it anyway, so why not put it in the legislation?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I trust that when I rose to my feet-rather ponderously, I thought-after Senator Campbell's address to close the debate I was not responsible for preventing Senator O'Chee from contributing anything to the second reading debate of this Bill, which of course he did not, but I do welcome his late contribution to the committee stage of the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: With respect to Senator O'Chee, I think he set, in his contribution, an impossible benchmark for the Council, which I think has an extraordinarily difficult task in front of it. Without being negative, which I was not, in agreeing with some of the comments made by Opposition speakers in this debate I said in my contribution to the second reading debate that I feel real limits will necessarily be placed on how this Council can function, and these may well fall far short of the expectations of many people intimately connected with the final outcome of this debate. Senator O'Chee said that it was necessary to establish these benchmarks so that the Council could `get it right the first time'. I think it is probably highly unlikely that the Council will get it right the first time.

To save time I will deal with all the amendments, including the ones on sitting fees, while I speak. Senator O'Chee mentioned the system of program budgeting. Senator Baume made a great contribution to the institution of program budgeting. I support program budgeting; I have been an adherent of it for years, and when I was a member of the Northern Territory Parliament I was very keen to see it happen. Indeed, I am pleased to say that the Northern Territory Government was one of the first governments in Australia to introduce the system of setting performance targets and having government departments be accountable in terms of how they met and tested those targets.

However, all of us who participate in Estimates committees know how difficult it is for the concept of program budgeting to be met in areas that deal with social justice. It is not that they cannot do it, but it is difficult to do it. It is very easy to introduce a program budgeting system, for example, in transport and works; if one has a budget of $600m a year and the target is to build X miles of road with it, it is easy to find out whether the money has been spent wisely and whether one has the required result. However, if I could just take what was formerly the Department of Aboriginal Affairs-now the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission-it is often extremely difficult, with the best will in the world, to set real performance indicators that actually serve some purpose to achieve a result on the amount of money spent that year in Aboriginal Affairs.

We can all determine what those desirable performance indicators are and I am sure we would all come up with the same ones because they are crude tools at best. We would all say that some of the benchmarks we should set in the administration of Aboriginal affairs would be a statistical reduction in the child mortality rate, a statistical reduction in the percentage of Aboriginal people occupying bed space in hospitals, a statistical reduction in the percentage of Aboriginal people who are inmates of our prison system and a statistical increase in the number of Aboriginal students achieving matriculation results, entrance to university and successful qualification on the gaining of degrees at the end of it.

These are benchmarks that I am sure the Aboriginal community, as well as the non-Aboriginal community, would agree are reasonable to set. They are more appropriately set-and are difficult enough to achieve even then-in the administration of Aboriginal affairs itself. It is an almost impossible task, with respect, at this point-when it has not even started-to set any meaningful benchmarks in an organisation which has the difficult, political and subjective task in front of it of trying to get some kind of meaningful reconciliation between the Aboriginal and the non-Aboriginal community in Australia.

Senator Baume enunciated for me in his original speech supporting these amendments the reason the Government at this point does not feel it is helpful to have benchmarks included in the legislation, and that is that under part 3 of the Bill the Council is required to develop a written strategy-it is required to set out its targets, in other words. It will become very obvious, very quickly I think, once it is put on paper, whether those targets are being met, whether benchmarks are set up or not. For that reason-I do not think that I am misinterpreting what Senator Baume said; it was the gravamen of his last remarks-the Government will not be supporting the amendment.

Again, I understand the import of what Senator Baume said about sitting fees, and I do not disagree with him. It is an area in which I have some personal experience. The difficulty with not allowing sitting fees is this: in the Aboriginal community with which I am familiar the same people, for obvious reasons, always tend to get picked by the Aboriginal community, as well as the non-Aboriginal community, to take on the responsible and onerous jobs of representing the community.

Senator Tambling knew, probably as well as I did, Silas Roberts, a very prominent Aboriginal figure in the Northern Territory who was literally-this is literally the truth-worked to death. He died at an early age, regrettably, from stress-in terms of my own knowledge of him-because he was on everything. He was appointed as the first Aboriginal magistrate and he was a member of the Aboriginal benefits trust association. We all know what happens. There is a lot of stress and a lot of pressure on a very small group of people who are capable of performing these roles.

A common situation is that a prominent person who works for the community is paid a wage by the community. He is on half a dozen important councils of direct involvement to that community's interests. He has constantly to go away to attend meetings of these councils. The communities themselves, with extremely limited budgets-I can assure honourable senators that Aboriginal communities do get very stringent local budgets-cannot afford, in terms of the often prolonged absences of these key people, not to replace them when they go away; they have to put people in their place to do the job. They then have to find funding for this. Usually people do this without pay. There was a very discriminatory situation where we literally could not get Aboriginal people to serve on some of these important councils because their employers were not in a position to continue paying them their salaries-nor was there any reasonable reason why they should have done so-while they were away from their job for prolonged periods. That is the problem.

I hope the result will be that those people on this Council who can afford not to receive the sitting fees will feel inclined-they might even do it collegiately-to donate their sitting fees to some worthy Aboriginal cause or organisation. Frankly, that is what I would do if I were appointed to such a council. Inevitably, there will be people who rightly should be considered for a place on this Council who simply cannot afford to do so because they will have to vacate their employment to be involved in something which will take up a fairly significant amount of time. The decision to introduce sitting fees was taken finally to avoid that discrimination. I hope that those who do not need the sitting fees will not keep them.

In conclusion, the Government-I know that I speak on behalf of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs when I say this-greatly welcomes and appreciates the reasons that Senator Baume gave for there being no divisions in this debate. We accept absolutely the strength that the Opposition places on these amendments. We do not take the view that it is not serious about them because it is not dividing on them. On behalf of the Government, I thank the Opposition for the reasons given publicly for there being no divisions on this legislation. It is greatly appreciated.
Amendments negatived.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
