DEBATE.TITLE: INTERSTATE ROAD TRANSPORT AMENDMENT BILL 1991INTERSTATE ROAD TRANSPORT CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 June, on motion by Senator Collins:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over 300,000 people are employed in the road transport industry in Australia. Their very livelihood and the livelihood of the many thousands more servicing the industry and, indeed, the well-being of the whole nation, depend on the industry's ability to make sensible changes to enhance a safe and efficient road transport industry. The Senate has before it two Bills on which hinge the future of the road transport industry in this country, namely, the Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill. If this legislation is not handled correctly, the industry, which is responsible for over 80 per cent of all freight movements in Australia, will emerge dispirited and disunited. This is something which must not be allowed to happen.

SPEECH.PARA: In handling these Bills for the Opposition, let me make it clear that the coalition will support the Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill, which allows for the introduction of B-doubles on Federal designated routes. However, we will seek to amend administrative aspects of this Bill at the committee stage to remove an inappropriate delegation of ministerial power. We will oppose the second reading of the Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill 1991 in the form of an amendment setting out all our particular concerns. I will move such an amendment at the end of my remarks.

Apparently, deals have been done by the Government with certain members of the national trucking industry. This is true to form. This Government is renowned for its partisan deals and fixes. The coalition was hoping that this legislation would focus on measures to increase national efficiency and international competitiveness and to move towards a more rational, national approach, instead of one impeded by obstacles put in place by State boundaries and individual State administrations. We hoped that the focus would target micro-economic reform in the area of road transport, but our hopes were forlorn.

Both these Bills were debated in the other place in early June under Government guillotine. As we know only too well, this prevented Australia's elected representatives from carrying out the job for which they are elected-that is, to participate in the serious debate of legislation before this Parliament-legislation required for an industry which is in dire need of urgent and desperate reform; legislation which should not be shunted through either the Senate or the other place in a matter of a few hours under the cover of tiredness after long hours of business or with waning interest.

Such legislation deserves a thorough investigation and analysis so that the problems of the industry can be dealt with diligently and with long term gains in mind. In the other place the Government muzzled debate because it did not want the issue in the spotlight, so we must ensure that in this place adequate time is devoted to effective debate of this very important legislation.

In the other place, the Government did not want the Australian public to see highlighted its impoverished mismanagement of what passes for our national road strategy because it is typical of how this rapidly decaying Government operates on all levels. In initiating this program there was delay after delay from a leader who wanted to bask in the light of eminence and renown just one more time at the recent Special Premiers Conference before he was swept from office.

The Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill 1991, as it is now presented, will allow B-doubles-double-bottomed trailers or, to the uninitiated, a prime mover with two trailers hitched-to operate under the Federal interstate registration scheme on designated routes. At long last, this means that these trucks will be able to operate right round Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I welcome the recognition by the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support of the importance of that decision. I am only sad that it has taken so long for this Government to achieve. The Government has procrastinated far too long on this issue to the detriment of the entire industry and those many others associated with it or dependent on it.

SPEECH.PARA: In bygone years, this soon to be bygone Government had the opportunity to introduce B-doubles nationally; it did not. Labor remained the last of the great regulators. It did not want these trucks moving out of the city zones, out of the delivery circuits ringing major centres. It wanted its inept railway union mates to get a slice of the action. It did not work, and now this Government is trying to make up for lost time while simultaneously dismantling the industry. The Government must have known for certain that allowing the introduction of these trailers would improve industry efficiency, but the question which will never be answered is why it has taken this tardy and tired Government so long to inch towards reform in the industry.

The operation of B-doubles under the Federal interstate registration scheme will obviate the need to obtain State permits-to date, a cumbersome and expensive, repetitive exercise. It will obviate that old trucking game-playing with the bureaucracy. Every time a truck needed to cross a State border or called into a weighbridge station, essential and necessary pieces of paper would fly around the truckie's cabin so that the truck could proceed and all would be well. Trucks may as well travel through foreign borders for the number of different State regulations they have to endure in this country.

The Northern Territory has been living with double and triple-bottoms for many years, but the Federal Government has been dithering about uniformly introduced B-doubles across Australia since 1985. Finally, it has been disgraced into taking action. After all, the United States has had B-doubles for 15 years, and innumerable isolated and remote communities across the United States have been benefiting from their advantages all this time.

It has long been recognised that the larger truck configurations are necessary to protect both the consumer and the community at large. The bigger the rig, the more freight that can be carried per tonne of pressure on the road, because the prime mover remains static and, as the size of the configuration is extended, the overall weight is less per tonnes of freight on board. In terms of road damage, that is very important.

Even three years ago the Inter-State Commission recommended that B-doubles be introduced as soon as practicable. As with countless other recommendations, no urgent action was ever taken, and now this Government on the nose has the temerity to announce such changes with gala fanfare, as though an innovation. Because of this short-sighted Government's ineptitude, over $1 billion has been lost to date in its battles with rail freight unions at the expense of the national trucking industry.

Let us recall that last year the railways in Australia lost $4 billion. That is more than State, local and Commonwealth governments combined spend on roads-$4 billion thrown to the wind. In fact, if the VicRail passenger transport system were closed today, sufficient money would be saved to purchase its regular commuters economical cars to drive themselves to work. Governments cannot go on spending that kind of money, and they certainly should not tax the shirts off the backs of the members of the transport industry as a quid pro quo for extending their network.

Only as we are being catapulted into the next century does this Government think it is about time to get a national rail freight centre up and running. By the time all the States fight the Commonwealth over that one, we will have arrived at the next century. By the time each State has decided what it has to gain and lose with rail freight, we can bet that another couple of years will have passed and nothing will have changed. By the time the rail unions have their slice, we can be assured that nothing will change.

When comparisons are made between B-doubles and conventionally articulated vehicles, the payload differential is some 11 tonnes. This represents productivity gains of some 40 per cent and efficiency gains of some 20 per cent overall after investment and operating costs are deducted. Cheaper costs should then be passed on to the consumer, and cheaper consumption goods mean more competitive exports for Australia. Even savings estimates of $250m per annum do not manage to convince this Government that it has made a serious error of judgment in delaying the introduction of B-doubles nationally-on these figures, $1.5 billion because of that delay alone.

Apart from consumer savings, there are savings on road wear costs per payload tonne-down 20 per cent for B-doubles when compared with articulated vehicles. Another aspect of the introduction of B-doubles, which may have been overlooked, comes from a study by the National Association of Australian State Road Authorities. It projected that up to 16 lives could be saved and 50 severe accidents could be avoided with the appearance of B-doubles on national roads.

That is because of the greater efficiency of these vehicles. Only 27 B-doubles are needed to carry 1,000 tonnes, but 38 conventionally articulated trucks are required to carry the same tonnage. So, in plain terms, the introduction of B-doubles would reduce the number of trucks on the roads. With improved road safety, less congestion, less noise and exhaust gases to cope with, all road users would gain.

The particular concern of the coalition with this legislation, however, relates to the increase in fines for overloading. There are too many inconsistencies between the States in regard to the laws associated with overloading. While some States are almost draconian in their pursuit of overloading and the enforcement process, other States reflect a more lenient approach, especially in regard to unintentional overloading. Trucking operators, if they can pull more freight with the same rig, will not have to drive so fast to make a living. Hence there will be less incentive to overload, with the resulting beneficial effect of less road damage. So a number of conflicts will have to be thoroughly overhauled before this legislation can be truly reflective of a national road strategy.

The second Bill, the Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill, seeks to change the present system, which allows only road maintenance costs to be taken into account in determining registration charges, and to limit registration charges which can be imposed on vehicles registered under the Federal interstate registration scheme. Hence the amendments enable the determination of Federal interstate registration scheme charges to be based on full cost recovery, taking into account construction and maintenance costs.

The coalition opposes this Bill, and I have circulated a second reading amendment which summarises our opposition. Charging for B-doubles should be considered in the context of the Special Premiers Conference held recently. By separating B-doubles from the charging regime discussions, the Government continues the ad hoc method of charging and road maintenance that has plagued the road system for years.

I note reports in this morning's press that cars are also now under consideration for inclusion in that scheme, again demonstrating the adhockery and the inconsistency in the development of this system. Their needs to be, in fact, consideration of the introduction of a complete and final package before any part of the package is introduced. Charging should be considered as a total package, since to have a relatively high cost attached to B-double operation will inhibit their introduction in the short run, at great cost to the wider community.

As usual, the Government has been contemptuous on this issue. After many years of dithering and procrastination, it has agreed to introduce a Federal interstate registration scheme, but after a slight pause it continues to tell us and the industry that it will hit operators for six and go for full cost recovery. That does not mean just the cost of daily wear and tear, but the actual costs associated with road construction.

No-one knows what these figures will eventually total. To date, the Government has not announced any specific figures-although I believe it has its best bean counters working on it-yet it seeks to impose a crippling financial burden on an industry which, I believe, already pays. As honourable senators may know, the special Premiers Conference agreed to the establishment of a national vehicle registration regulation and charging scheme. All, except the Northern Territory, agreed to the changes.

The focus of this new scheme is the establishment of a National Road Transport Commission to regulate heavy vehicles on a nationally uniform basis and to develop a heavy vehicle charging scheme. With regard to the charging scheme, the coalition agrees in principle-as do many in the industry-that road pricing should be on a more rational basis. However, we believe that it should be done on a fair basis. There are some very real concerns about the wording of the Premiers Conference communique.

First of all, the road charging principles outlined delineate zones on the basis of State borders. It is not clear that the difference between remote areas in New South Wales and Victoria and remote areas in other States requires that those areas should face differing charges. The coalition has repeatedly called for an economic impact statement on the effect of the changes on rural and remote areas before any are finalised.

Secondly, it appears that the mass distance charges are based on average mass and average distance for different types of trucks while the actual classifications of trucks are yet to be specified. Imposing the average on large chunks of the road transport industry will prove to be extremely unfair to many operators, particularly those who travel only short distances. Thirdly, the actual specifications of how frequent the mass distance charge payments will be are not clear. An up-front payment for the whole year, based on averages, may prove to be too onerous for many operators.

The industry argues that it already more than covers the cost of the roads that its drivers travel on, since it pays 3.5 times as much tax as any other industry. According to the Inter-State Commission Report on road user charging and vehicle registration, this claim is, in fact, confirmed.

Any review of charging should be done in the context of a review of the total tax burden on the industry. The road transport industry forum indicated in its document Blueprint for Industry Reform that the industry should, at most, only have to pay for the maintenance costs caused by the wear that road transport causes to the road network. All construction costs should be met out of Consolidated Revenue. It argues that the industry should only have to pay an amount equal to the private benefit gained from having roads constructed to a standard to carry heavy vehicles. The remaining construction costs should be paid out of Consolidated Revenue, as all the community benefits from it. The blueprint also outlines the need for a better understanding of the industry.

More than 80 per cent of all freight in Australia is carried by road. Irrespective of any rail reforms, it will continue to service the vast majority of local, regional and national requirements. It is not just the industry operators who pay; it is the users of the payloads who pay-farmers, manufacturers, businesses, individuals. If we had a superior and efficient rail freight network, these additional costs would not exist. The rail system would pay its own way and not be subsidised to the hilt.

The Government does not agree. It says that the road industry still does not pay enough. Yet there is a vast array of data to give testimony to the fact that an ordinary owner driver pays 33 per cent of his revenue in tax, in one form or another. If all contributions that operators pay were directed to roads-keeping in mind that billions of dollars are paid out in road transport around the country-we certainly would not have to worry about the standard of our roads. In fact, we could probably have cars on the road with no registration fees at all. Also, Mr and Mrs Average car driver would not have to pay through the nose for the privilege of driving on our shabby roads. It is worth remembering that on the whole, since our nation has become more mobile, most roads have been constructed with the motor car in mind. They will still shadow snaking railway lines around this country for a long time to come.

The coalition wants impartiality. That is why we want road transport-especially B-doubles-not to go the way of the dinosaur, and not to be taxed within an inch of its life. It will be found that in past years many operators have paid sales tax of about 50 cents a tonne on tyres alone to move tonnage about 1,500 kilometres. The Government cannot tell me that road transport does not pay its way; it certainly does. Operators pay, and the coalition is reluctant to see this chamber agree to any additional imposts placed on the industry before we even know what those imposts will be-and certainly before massive changes are made in the rail freight industry and this Government's snug deal with its railway union mates is eliminated.

We should not-we cannot-agree to a litany of charges imposing cost recovery when the Government has not even worked out what they will be. That is sheer lunacy. We will wait and we will decide when the beans are on the table. The coalition is not against user pays. We are in favour of it. However, the transport industry is already slugged with costs which have sent many of its operators and supporters to the wall in recent years. Now the Government presents us with this legislation for which, essentially, it has no cost figures. If it has no cost figures, how can it make a case for charges to recover those costs?

It is no wonder that the transport industry was uncertain about discussions at the recent special Premiers Conference. There is little doubt that additional costs imposed on the trucking industry will be immediately passed on to the consumer, if these truckies are to stay in business. They will not wear them. Why should they? The users of the road transport network will leave in droves. As the only other choice is rail, that really is no choice at all.

In recent weeks we have heard the President of the Road Transport Federation, Mr Peter Rocke, express his concern about additional road costs. He proposes that they will most certainly be passed on to consumers. Where is the sense in that? It is simply adding to the overall costs of operation and costs of industry inputs. This Government may just as well place a direct tax on individual consumers. It could call it a negligence tax because it has totally neglected the national freight movement for so long.

At the recent special Premiers Conference, that same conference that the almost once again charismatic Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) claimed was the most important Premiers Conference in Australia since the Second World War, we also heard--

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be his last one.

—It will be his last one, as Senator Panizza says; he has not long to remain in office. The road industry forum is extremely unhappy about plans to require long distance trucks to pay the full cost of the damage they allegedly cause to the roads.

SPEECH.PARA: Even Wayne Goss, Queensland's Labor Premier-a Labor premier who thinks, at least sometimes-was concerned when the proposal was put forward. Perhaps the Prime Minister should listen to him. Wayne Goss claimed that it would have a very damaging effect on regional Australia, with a huge cost burden not just for the transport industry but for significant rural industries. It would also mean a substantial increase in the cost of living in regional Queensland. Premier Goss is right. He knows that Queensland could not survive on regional freight centres alone-it is not practical for such an expanse of territory. Nor could the west. The Northern Territory has fewer than 200 kilometres of rail to the South Australian border and no railway east or north. Similarly, in my own State of South Australia, Eyre Peninsula, which lacks a rail link to the rest of the State, would be hit to leg.

Even the Queensland Premier estimates that the costs of these proposals for various rural industries will add up to tens of millions of dollars each and, in some cases, increase the cost of living by between one per cent and 4 per cent, depending on where one lives in Queensland. Of course, the same effects will be felt in other remote parts of Australia- in the Northern Territory and in South Australia and Western Australia especially. This heartless, indeed mindless, Government has chosen conveniently to ignore the impact which these cost burdens will have on industries and individuals cornered by this ill conceived legislation.

We have heard that an interim commission is to be established by September this year to assist in developing legislation and to begin work on regulation, registration and charging issues. We are told that planning is to commence immediately to interlink the existing set of motor registries, allow for the automatic exchange of defect notices, allow a simplified number plate system and facilitate the development of registration procedures so that information on all heavy vehicles is available nationally by July next year. Additionally, the Federal interstate registration scheme is to be subsumed into the national heavy vehicles scheme.

The complete detail of the discussions relating to the charging structures is not known to me, but it would appear that the following has emerged from the July Special Premiers Conference: a charging structure is to be implemented comprising a nominal administration charge, a road use charge component of Commonwealth diesel excise and a registration or mass distance charge for vehicles which do not meet their road costs through fuel payments alone.

The road use part of diesel excise is to be structured to avoid the administratively cumbersome imposition of registration or mass distance charges on a significant proportion of the vehicle fleet. The registration charge is to be applied to heavy vehicles where it would be inequitable; that is, it would involve significant over recovery for other vehicles if they covered their road costs by fuel charges alone.

Apparently, charges are always to be set: firstly, to recover fully distributed road costs, thereby achieving full recovery of all road costs by minimising over recovery from any vehicle class; secondly, to determine and collect charges in a way that achieves a reasonable balance between administrative simplicity, efficiency and equity in the charging structure; thirdly, to improve pricing, leading to a better allocation of resources with investment decisions being based on more relevant demand signals; and, fourthly, to minimise the incentive for operators to `shop around' for lower charges and undermine the integrity of the national charging system.

The Minister and this Government are just isolating one group of road users and trying to tax them off our roads. I do not believe that it is consistent, nor morally right, that these trucks should be charged at a different rate from other trucks already using the roads which will be their competitors. The Government knows full well that these trucks will be a direct competitor with the interstate rail system, so the Minister just blows them off the road. He has become the Mad Max of the Labor Government.

I remind the Minister that in 1988 the then Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Gareth Evans, gave a guarantee to members of the transport industry that an inquiry into registration charges would take into account the relative cost recovery and efficiency performance of equivalent rail services and all fuel product excise payments by the industry. That is clearly an undertaking which has yet to be taken up. The Minister stated:

The Government will retain the principles included in the existing legislation that the Federal registration charges are determined on the basis of road damage and that the practice of including limits on the level of charges in the legislation will be continued.

That was three years ago. It would appear that the Minister has forgotten it in the case of applying these principles to B-doubles. If the Government does deal with certain groups within the trucking industry and pits conventional articulated vehicle operators against B-double operators, it is doing the whole industry a grave disservice.

A prime mover that pulls a B-double can just as easily pull a single articulated trailer. That is why the coalition wants a second reading amendment requiring charging rates for B-doubles consistent with the charging rates for other semitrailers and heavy vehicles that are registered under the Federal interstate registration system. Despite this, the coalition reservedly supports the principles of the legislation, even if they have been a long time coming.

The Minister knows his Government should have taken action years ago, but that is not enough to win our support for this Bill. Legislation should not be enacted until there is a consistent approach and a comprehensive set of charges. It is a great pity that, at the same time, a rail network strategy will not be put in place so the two transport networks could complement each other instead of cutting each others throats while suffering loathing and contempt.

Those intervening years have left a legacy of bankruptcies, a lack of industry confidence, poor productivity and spiralling costs for an industry which should have been treated better from the outset. Australia is too large for either just the railways to move goods to and fro or for road operators to transport tonnage. A national trucking strategy is long overdue for this country and it should have the capacity to make major contributions in micro-economic reform.

The Minister knows that its difficult birth has cost this country over $1 billion, but at the same time he wants to tax the new baby before it is even in nappies. That is why the coalition cannot support this legislation.

We want to see further initiatives in tackling the problems associated with the National Rail Freight Centre; we want to see the railways made efficient freight movers; we want to see the railways begin to show some returns; we want to see rationalisation of their manning levels; and we want the road transport system and the rest of the country to stop paying for the legacy of ineptitude evident in our railways. Australia just simply cannot afford any inefficiencies in any part of the transport industry.

We cannot afford to have our most efficient transport sector being unfairly treated while the inefficient ones are allowed to continue to cost the country billions of dollars. We cannot afford to let the rorts prevalent on our waterfront remain entrenched in our railway transport network. In conclusion, as an amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill 1991, I move:
Leave out all words after ``That'', substitute:

``the Senate is of the opinion that the method of determining registration charges for B-Doubles should be consistent with existing Federal Interstate Registration Scheme (FIRS) principles and should not be varied until such time as it is possible to implement a comprehensive and consistent set of charges in respect of the national road transport industry''.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to support the comments of my colleague Senator Chapman in addressing the Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill 1991. The implications and ramifications of the issues that will flow from this legislation are far reaching and will have a dramatic effect on all Australians. In particular, I would like to speak for those Australians who live in rural and remote Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: It is evident from the recent Premiers Conference that neither the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) nor any State Premier knows or understands the economic impact of these proposals at the supermarket shelf. Really, that is where it has to count. We in the Senate represent ordinary, average Australian families. To increase road freight registration charges by almost 3,000 per cent within the next nine years, without taking into account the consequential cost flow-ons that will affect people living in rural and remote Australia, is, indeed, a very serious matter.

The cross-subsidies being forced on rural and remote regions to subsidise the highly urbanised States and their congested and often ineffective road transport systems certainly need major review. My colleague the shadow Minister for land transport, David Hawker, has continually called for an economic assessment and review to take into account the issues that must be addressed in rural and remote Australia and in particular, any new charging regime that applies to the trucking industry. It is obvious that the Government is not serious in addressing this particular issue.

From 24 to 26 March, I attended a conference in Alice Springs organised by the Federal Department of Transport and Communications and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy under the chairmanship and the auspices of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications, Warren Snowdon. That conference put down a heck of a lot of issues needing serious consideration.

Reviewing the report subsequently prepared from that conference, it is interesting to read through the main issues and the recommendations that arose. The chapter headings are: The Significance of Rural and Remote Australia; Planning and Coordination of the Transport Infrastructure and Services in Rural and Remote Australia; Transport Infrastructure, Funding and Charging; Consultation; Uniformity of Regulations; Community Service Obligations; Taxation and Charges Applying to Rural and Remote Areas; Rural Incomes; and Prices of Fuel and Other Household Items.

The report is comprehensive. It outlines the concerns of many of the participants, the great majority of whom were public servants drawn either from the Federal or State bureaucracies throughout Australia. I was concerned that a press release that was put out at the time of the report's release by the chairman of the conference, Warren Snowdon, highlighted only three particular elements of a proposed strategy. They were, to quote from Mr Snowdon's press release: research to begin shortly to identify impacts to consumers and primary producers in rural and remote Australia of the overarching group's recommendations; the Federal Government to recommend at the Special Premiers Conference that no binding decisions on actual charging levels will be made until the results of this research are known; and to recommend to State and Territory governments that proposals to introduce special treatment for rural and remote areas such as zonal arrangements be seriously considered in the light of the research findings. These are pious words from the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications.

If we look in detail at the report, both at the executive summary and at the recommendations, it is interesting to note that there were not three points put forward by that conference but in fact 24 specific recommendations. Those recommendations, which were important for government to consider, looked not only at the impact on living standards and the existing transport infrastructure but also at the issues that would impact on business, industry, primary production and on people who live in the remote areas of Australia.

I discussed this report earlier in the chamber with the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support who was then on duty, Senator Collins, and obtained his permission to incorporate in Hansard the executive summary and the recommendations of that Alice Springs report. I seek leave to do so.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The ``Transport in Rural and Remote Australia Conference'' was instigated to provide a forum for government, industry and community representatives to discuss transport and transport related issues in rural and remote Australia.

The Conference emphasised the economic, social and cultural significance of rural and remote areas to Australia as a nation and urged continued commitment to the principles embodied in the Prime Minister's 1989 Rural and Regional Statement.

Specific consideration was given to current issues, in particular the Interstate Commission Report on ``Road User Charging-A National Scheme''. The Conference strongly urged detailed analysis of the likely impact on rural and remote communities of the ISC report and related proposals. The Conference supported immediate research and ongoing monitoring of road user charges to provide adequate information for governments, to decide whether any steps are needed to ameliorate significant adverse effects on regions or industry sectors.
Longer term structural and policy directions were also discussed and three major issues identified.

Firstly, the Conference strongly urged all governments to implement more extensive and more appropriate consultation with a broader spectrum of representatives of rural and remote areas. The Conference acknowledged the role of industry peak bodies but argued that consultation should also extend to regionalised representatives and local community groups. Delegates believed that it was important that this consultation be done in a more appropriate timeframe so that those groups being consulted would have adequate time to consider and comment on proposals.

Delegates believed that this consultation would address the second major issue arising from the Conference, that is the need for detailed assessment and appropriate consideration of the impact of policies in rural areas before implementation. Delegates stressed that policy makers need to acknowledge that particular policies may impact on different areas in significantly different ways as a result of the social, economic, physical and infrastructure characteristics of the areas.

Thirdly the Conference urged greater attention be given to options for integrating the planning and coordination of transport and transport related policies in rural and remote areas. The Conference stressed the benefits of planning decisions more closely reflecting local economic and social needs, and the need for greater coordination in investment and policy decisions by providers of transport and transport related and complementary services and infrastructure, to enable the most appropriate and most cost effective services to be provided.
The Conference stressed that this was particularly important in addressing community service obligations in rural and remote areas.

The prices of fuel and other household items were also of concern to the Conference and delegates questioned the effectiveness of the Petroleum Products Freight Subsidy Scheme and the adequacy of other compensatory mechanisms such as tax zone rebates in addressing consistently higher prices in these areas.
RECOMMENDATIONS

(1) the Federal Government maintain and increase its commitment to improving the living standards of people in rural areas by implementing actions consistent with the principles embodied in the Prime Minister's 1989 Statement.

(2) the Federal Government recognise the significance of transport in improving the living standards of people in rural areas and the need to provide adequate infrastructure and services on a social justice basis, particularly with regard to the needs of Aboriginal communities.
(3) a comprehensive data base of the existing transport infrastructure in rural and remote areas be developed by State and Territory Government transport portfolios

(4) a working party of state government representatives and key national community representatives review regulations and policies applying to use of transport services and infrastructure to enhance the accessibility and utilisation of these resources in rural and remote areas
(5) Governments assess the need to jointly undertake analysis of the impact of economic structural adjustment and social policies, on rural and remote areas
(6) The Federal Government consider the need for a review of the suitability of existing vehicle design and manufacturing standards for rural and remote Australia

(7) Governments be encouraged to consult with each other in the preparation of transport strategies and to coordinate policy formulation with particular reference to transport services for remote and rural Australia
(8) providers of transport services be encouraged to consult with affected communities prior to making investment decisions
(9) immediate research be undertaken to accurately establish the real impact of any increased road user charges on rural and remote areas
(10) the need for ongoing monitoring and research into road user charges be acknowledged and mechanisms be established to enable this to occur

(11) governments monitor the impact of any changes and give consideration to the need for measures to lessen the disadvantages that may be experienced in the short term by particular sectors or regions as a result of reforms in the transport sector

(12) road user charging arrangements should reflect the costs of road use, but recognise the dependence of rural and remote Australia on road transport and the social and developmental role that road infrastructure plays in these areas
(13) any road user charging system be guided by the principles of:
* simplicity
* easily understood by users
* difficult to avoid and simple to enforce
(14) transport policy makers should consult more widely and in a more appropriate timeframe with relevant groups on objectives, priorities and specific policy proposals
(15) information provided about policy proposals be appropriate to the particular audience
(16) a national body be established to pursue uniformity in technical and operating regulations for heavy vehicles and seek to reduce the total amount of regulation governing the transport industry
(17) nationally uniform regulations that recognise differences in regional operating conditions be developed
(18) an appropriate manual be developed for industry use detailing regulations for ready reference
(19) the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics be requested to examine the community service obligation component in the provision of road infrastructure and rail passenger services

(20) The Department of Primary Industries and Energy work with state governments, key community organisations and industry to identify and assess the appropriateness of existing community service obligations of government services in rural and remote areas

(21) Federal, State and Territory Governments examine the incidence and the impact of all direct and indirect taxes, charges, rebates, subsidies and concessions applying in rural and remote areas with a view to enhancing the effectiveness and equity of these measures.
(22) that timing or phasing in of necessary reforms take account of implications for sectors or regions affected by the current downturn in rural industries
(23) The Federal Government review the current Petroleum Products Freight Subsidy Scheme to ensure the objective of equality in access to goods and services is being achieved.

(24) the Australian Bureau of Statistics in conjunction with the RPPU, of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, the Australian Taxation Office and the Prices Surveillance Authority develop an appropriate weighting mechanism and undertake a survey of household prices in rural and remote areas to determine, inter alia, whether current compensatory mechanisms (taxation zonal rebate) are adequate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. It is important, as we face next week's Federal Budget, that we look for a very specific response to this particular conference report on transport. Mr Snowdon has indicated that it will be forthcoming as part of the Budget deliberations; I certainly hope so. I want to see a specific response to every one of the 24 recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: In light of the fact that the Prime Minister and the Premiers have now proceeded down a completely different track, probably pre-empting many of those recommendations, it will be interesting to see how seriously the Government has responded to each and every one of those conference recommendations. It was a conference that the Department and the Government set up to solicit those particular views; a conference that the Government asked for that report; a conference that the Government funded totally, at some considerable cost; and a conference at which the participants were primarily Federal bureaucrats or State bureaucrats with a particular interest in the transport portfolio.

As you know, Mr Acting Deputy President, I represent the Northern Territory. The Northern Territory Government was the only government that stood aside from the recent agreement between the Prime Minister and the Premiers on land transport. I note that the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, the Hon. Marshall Perron, has quite strongly taken the view that the impacts of the decision that has been taken primarily by the Prime Minister and forced on the Australian community do need to be addressed.

Senator Chapman has today outlined all of the issues that impact on this particular proposal. Whether they are in the associated transport fields of railway or shipping, it is interesting to note that the Commonwealth has continually reneged on its promises to the Northern Territory for a period going back some 80 years. In 1911, the Commonwealth made a commitment to complete the rail link from Alice Springs to Darwin. In the Northern Territory we are still waiting for that promise to be honoured. It is only when we get independent governments that seek to put that in place with commercial interests that there will be any hope that in the future we will see an alternative rail system which would then bring the Northern Territory into a system that could act in concert and in partnership with the rest of Australia.

It is not just the Northern Territory that will feel the impacts of this legislation and these government decisions. This legislation will have very serious impacts on Queensland, which you represent, Mr Acting Deputy President, and also on Western Australia. There are important industries that will be affected. Over 40 per cent of Australia's export industries come from northern Australia. The financial implications of those transport arrangements are crucial to the industries that have to survive in that part of Australia.

There are thousands of Australians who choose to associate themselves with these industries and to live in and develop the north, central and outback parts of Australia, which will feel very adversely the effects of these charges. SPEECH.PARA: We cannot support a second reading attachment that seeks to delay a process, the ultimate goal of which we believe in. Land transport accounts for more than 20 per cent of Australia's emission of greenhouse gases. Most of this is due to the use of some 16,000 million litres of petrol a year. To rescue our future, Australia must reduce these emissions by more than 90 per cent by the year 2030, as the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology recognised was necessary in its 1991 report.

Our national accounting system has never acknowledged the need to incorporate the true social and financial costs of road crashes, road congestion, noise pollution and the emission of 20 per cent of Australia's greenhouse gases. At the same time, Australia's self-sufficiency in petroleum is expected to decline from near 90 per cent to between 20 and 50 per cent by the year 2000. SPEECH.PARA: We have seen transport investment policies that continue a bias in favour of energy wasteful, oil dependent activities which are likely to have a crippling effect on our balance of payments within the next 20 years. Yet, fuel savings resulting not from having more B-doubles and fewer articulated vehicles on the road but from the use of rail transport as opposed to road transport can be up to four times greater. So, not only social and environmental costs but also financial commonsense justify revitalising a national system of rail freight.

The Federal Government in its Energy 2000 report noted that shifts from long distance road transport to rail or sea would be more likely if there were full recovery of road costs due to heavy trucks. The Government's best intentions to establish by 1 July 1991 the National Rail Freight Corporation in recognition of this seem to have sunk in a quagmire of conflicting interests. Action is urgently required. I know that my own home State of Queensland has been somewhat obstreperous in this process.

The Democrats argue that this Government has exaggerated the financial problems facing rail transport. We think it has placed too much emphasis on the micro-economic cure-alls of labour productivity and on the miracle of full road cost recovery. But it has not paid sufficient attention to the more efficient solutions such as the expansion of government rail systems or even the technical aspects of running trains efficiently. In fact, this Federal Government has spent so little on rail that it is currently in receipt of net revenue from Australia's railways.

The Federal Government's allocations to the States for rail investment in the eight years of this Labor Government have declined by 80 per cent. The Federal Government's spending on roads has increased to a massive $10.851 billion compared with $505m on rail; that is, less than 5 per cent of the money allocated to roads has been allocated to rail.

The figures are even more disgraceful when we realise that the $500m includes the revenue supplement paid to Australian National Railways. This subsidy paid to Australian National has totalled over $500m during this Government's term of office. If these payments are excluded, it is clear that the Commonwealth's contribution to the improvement of this nation's rail system has been close to zero. Although railways perform about 43 per cent of Australia's land freight transport task, compared with 60 per cent in the gas guzzling United States, they have received only 4 per cent of Commonwealth allocations for land transport investment during the past 20 years.

From 1983 to 1988, the railways paid $436m to the Commonwealth in fuel excise, of which $105m has been calculated by the Australian Conservation Foundation and the Australian Railways Union as having gone directly into road funding. So do not let us hear the Opposition stand up here and say that there have been no subsidies. There certainly have been indirect subsidies to road transport in this country.

Since 1983, the Commonwealth Government has spent about $730m on improving the Hume Highway but not one dollar on the adjacent Sydney-Melbourne mainline railway; that is, more than $10 billion to roads and nothing to rail. These figures show a Government bias towards road funding at the expense of railways. Put another way, it shows bias towards road haulage big business at the expense of the national interest. I think the Government has recognised this imbalance.

We have seen many announcements about a land transport program but, in the hiatus between what the Federal Government says it intends to do and what it has not yet done, the cash starved State railways are closing country rail with damaging social costs to rural communities and the Australian National Line is pulling up railway lines and forcing staple rail cargoes on to the road. There is no coordination here. The Federal Government is setting up a national freight system; State governments are closing them down; and rural communities are left with no choice but to use road transport.

National Rail Freight Corporation or not, the Government should, by now, have reached a stage where it is prepared to commit investment to interstate mainline upgrading along the lines recommended by the national freight initiative of 1990. There should be minimum requirements for improved freight terminals in the five mainland State capitals plus very basic track work, along with Adelaide-Melbourne gauge standardisation. It should be working to bring the Sydney-Melbourne line to fast freight train standards. I know the Government has been arguing for `user pays'; so has the Opposition. That is fine. The Government could make a start by using the $500m or more that the railways have paid to the Commonwealth in fuel excise to fund the basic upgrading of the lines I have just mentioned.

Australia cannot afford to wait the years it will take for the diverse vested interests in the trucking industry and the States to agree to low road cost recovery payments for heavy trucks. We cannot afford to wait for the five States to agree to relinquish their constitutional powers over the railways. Unless the Federal Government acts now to outlay for the basic minimum requirement to get freight back on the railway track, the deficit on interstate rail freight operations in Australia will remain high, resulting in more and more trucks-probably B-doubles-on our major highways, more pollution, more road trauma and the disappearance of almost all our regional rail trunk routes.

To us, this is the ultimate user pays because users are paying proportionately for their consumption of the resources of this nation. Before we anticipate too much noise from Opposition speakers about how this will result in registration charges of something like $55,000, let me read the following report in the Australian Financial Review:
But officials yesterday indicated that the proposals put before the premiers had suggested that the highest rate for heavy vehicles be about $7,000 . . .
While the system would be revenue-neutral, the standardisation of registration charges would see more vehicles paying the top rate while lighter vehicles would actually have their rate reduced.

This is a complex issue. We have a long way to go. There is a place for both road and rail in this country. Certainly rail has been disadvantaged. It holds the key to the future and we must look very seriously at implementing the many reports we have seen which tell us what needs to be done urgently. We must take action as soon as we can, and we must hope that we will see greater cooperation from the States.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are addressing the Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill 1991 and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill 1991. I have listened to the contributions of previous speakers. Before Senator Kernot leaves the chamber I would like to ask her: does rail not use fuel? When goods are moved by electric rail, power has to be generated. Therefore, there is still pollution.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill amends the Interstate Road Transport Act 1985 and provides for the registration and regulation of prime movers-I emphasise `prime movers'; they are not trailers-which are to be used as part of the B-double combination under the Federal interstate registration scheme. The amendments further provide for the regulation of those vehicles and State registered trailers. If I read the legislation correctly, only the prime movers will be registered under the new system; trailers will still be registered under the State system when operating as part of a B-double combination. Of course, operation of the B-double under the Federal interstate registration scheme will obviate the need to obtain State permits. The amendments provide a head of power to make regulations covering roadworthiness, which is important; designation of routes and technical requirements as to mass limits; dimensions, and so on.

Perhaps I should describe a B-double. It is simply a prime mover-say, a six-wheel prime mover-fitted with a turntable on which the first semi-trailer is virtually connected but, because there are two trailers, the second trailer does not have a tow bar and a turntable. The turntable for the back trailer is mounted on the rear of the front trailer. That is how it works. I have operated one myself. It makes the vehicle a lot more roadworthy. The third trailer on a road train tends to move around. Such a vehicle can track a lot better and it is an improvement when taking corners, especially in city areas where the streets and roads are not so wide.

At present, all States allow for the operation of B-doubles on designated routes. Tasmania is an exception and, up until a few weeks ago, Victoria allowed them only in limited areas; they were not able to operate widely under any regulation. This is what this legislation is all about. If Victoria had played ball in the first place, I believe we would not have had this legislation at this time-we would have waited until the whole new scheme of national registration and regulation had come in.

Honourable senators may remember that a report on grain handling storage some four or five years ago recommended that B-doubles be licensed in Australia. It has taken at least four years to get anywhere near that position. According to some speeches to date and discussions in the media, B-doubles are something new. We have been slow in taking up this concept in Australia. Senator Chapman said that they have been in use in the United States for 15 years. I can state that they have been in use in New Zealand, just on our doorstep, for the last 15 years. I am at a loss to understand why they have not been introduced into Australia before now. However, they seem to be on the way now.

In order for the full benefits offered by B-doubles to be realised, it is necessary to operate on a uniform basis across Australia. To date, each State has made its own arrangements. As I have said, Tasmania barred them altogether and Victoria allowed them to be used in only a limited way. The advantage of such vehicles is that, compared with a standard semitrailer which can have a payload of 26 tonnes, a B-double can have up to 37 tonnes. After taking into account additional capital costs for the B-doubles and other operational costs, efficiency improvements will be in the range of 20 per cent. Actual efficiency is 40 per cent, but the extra costs bring it down. Lower transport costs are passed on as reductions. These should amount to about $250m, which will provide cheaper consumer goods and more competitive exports.

Road wear has a great bearing on this also. There is much better tracking with a B-double system. A cut in road wear of 20 per cent can occur by using these vehicles rather than conventional large vehicles. B-doubles have a better safety record because of their improved stability, as I have said, and they have a 25 per cent higher roll-over tolerance than conventional vehicles. A study by the National Association of Australian State Road Authorities has predicted that introducing B-doubles throughout Australia would save 16 lives and 50 serious accidents per year.

TALK.START.PARA: —What?
—Those figures are right, I think. Are those figures right, Senator Collins?
—Through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, they are.
—Senator West really knows her business, doesn't she?

—As Senator West has spoken on various items of rural legislation, such as wool-as Senator Knowles has pointed out-I would have thought that she would have known a bit about the transport needed to shift this wool to the market.
—Yes, I do.

—Perhaps she has had experience driving trucks; she can tell us later on. Only 27 B-doubles are needed to carry 1,000 tonnes, whereas 38 conventional vehicles would have to be used for the same task. This would reduce the increasing number of trucks on the road. We have been told by Senator Kernot that there will be virtually a doubling of trucks on the roads by the year 2000. If this Government's economic performance continues for much longer, I doubt whether there will be any such increases. With these vehicles we will have improved road safety, less congestion, less noise and less exhaust pollution, which Senator Kernot talks about so much. I certainly applaud the move to finally get these B-doubles on the road. As I said before, they have been a long time in coming. If we get them on the road, and we get the rest of the national registration scheme which we were supposed to get some time ago, it will be a great boon to transport in Australia.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Employment, Education and Training: Rural Youth

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services. What is the Government doing to ensure access by rural and isolated young people to information on employment, education and training?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously, this is one area to which the Government is paying some attention. We have introduced a package of measures to provide rural young people with access to services and programs. There are a number of measures, but I think one of the most important ones is the rural youth information service, a general service which helps local young people to make informed decisions about education, training, occupations and their future.

ANSWER.PARA: It should be noted that on 8 August, when opening the Hay rural youth information service, Mr Baldwin, the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, announced the Government's continued support for the program and also the funding of 13 additional services, bringing the total to 23 services nationally. Furthermore, five mobile youth access centres are being piloted to establish a cost-efficient yet comprehensive service to isolated young people. As I said at the outset, the Government does recognise a need in this area.
