TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer the Minister to his obfuscation yesterday in answer to my question concerning public sector wage deals and proceedings in the Australian Industrial Relations Commission yesterday. I ask the Minister: will the public sector receive the accord agreement, regardless of any Industrial Relation Commission decision which has been, or may be, made about this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I reject the assertion at the head of this question that I obfuscated yesterday; I did not. I rejected then--
—Read today's press.

—If the honourable senator believes everything he reads in the newspapers then he is a very credulous person. I rejected then the implication that Senator Durack chose to try to draw in his question, and I reject it again today. In light of proceedings, this is, on the surface, an innocent question but it is, in reality, a mischievous one.

ANSWER.PARA: The Opposition knows that, as a government, we are bound by the accord and that we are determined to honour our obligations under the accord. Those opposite know that we have settled a framework agreement with public sector unions to pay accord mark VI which involves the payment of a $12 wage increase for continued award restructuring from 16 May and involves the negotiation, in three tranches, of productivity increases between now and September next year.

The Opposition knows that we have applied, with the unions in the public sector, to the Industrial Relations Commission for the $12. The Opposition knows as well that in that application the Industrial Relations Commission chose to convert our $12 wage application to a 2.5 per cent wage increase. I have to say that I have criticised unabashedly the Industrial Relations Commission for insisting on a 2.5 per cent wage increase instead of a $12 flat wage increase.

The reason why I have done so is best illustrated by this case: if a person is an Australian Public Service fat cat on $100,000 per year, 2.5 per cent is worth $2,500; but if a person is a Public Service thin cat on $20,000 per year, it is worth only $500 per year. That is to say, if a person is a thin cat he or she will get $2,000 per year less, but that person will have to pay exactly the same amount for a loaf of bread or the necessities of life as the fat cat does.

As far as the Labor Government is concerned, we think there ought to be some evening out on wage increases and those at the lower end of the wage scale should be entitled to a reasonable increase. If that means that those at the upper end of the wage scale get less, so be it; that is fair. At the lower end of the scale every cent is important. While $12 may not be important to the honourable senator on his salary, $12 is important for someone on $20,000 per year because the value of money is much more vital to that person. I now turn to the question--

TALK.START.PARA: —What happened to the umpire?

—That is my criticism of the umpire: in short, low wage earners in this country who have suffered the brunt of the recession have been gypped by the umpire. In essence, that is my criticism of the umpire.

ANSWER.PARA: I now come to the answer to this question. On 9 August I put out a press release which said that I had proposed an offer to Public Service unions. In the wage application yesterday my advocate-the advocate representing the Government-made it clear during the proceedings, as did the ACTU, that that offer in the terms of my agreement was not the offer that was the subject of the application. The application was in a different form and we stood by that application. I refer honourable senators to the transcript of those proceedings.

Yesterday I put out a press release on the basis of that and acknowledged that; so the record is clear. It is also clear in the record of the proceedings-in fact, in the decision of the Commission-that the Commission recognises the fact that the Government will honour its undertaking to pay a $12 wage increase up until the time of the Commission's order, that is $12 from 16 May, and that that will be a decision, in the end, for Parliament. The Commission recognises that. But it is my intention-let me be unequivocal on this point-to ask the head of the Department of Industrial Relations, who is the delegate for the purposes of the Act, to make a determination to pay $12 back to 16 May in view of yesterday's decision.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Discharge of Ballast Water by Ships

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. I refer to the recent release of a report by the Bureau of Rural Resources reviewing the potential problems posed to our marine environment from the discharge of ships' ballast water in Australian ports. Can the Minister advise what is being done to counter this menace to our aquatic life?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a serious international problem in terms of the great volume of this ballast material which is discharged around the world by ships, and which does contain exotic organisms. Unfortunately, there are no simple solutions to the problem. It is not just a matter of ordering vessels to discharge ballast waters taken on board overseas before they reach Australia because if we did that, it would, in turn, cause very serious dangers to the structure and stability of larger vessels.

ANSWER.PARA: In Australia, voluntary guidelines have been in place since February last year covering the discharge of ballast water by foreign vessels visiting Australia. These guidelines are administered by Australian quarantine officials working closely with the Australian Maritime Safety Authority. In the international sphere, Australia has taken a leading role in addressing this issue.

In July, Australia chaired the meeting of the working group of the International Maritime Organisation's committee on marine environment protection, which finalised international guidelines this year on the discharge of ballast water by ships. The guidelines, both local and international, are recognised as an interim measure to allow further research into alternative techniques. I am advised by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority that there has been a very high level of compliance by foreign ships with these guidelines.

Currently, there is an intensive research effort under way involving the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, AMSA, the Department of Transport and Communications, CSIRO and industry to examine the scientific, technical, economic and regulatory aspects of ballast control measures. The recent report by the Bureau of Rural Resources reflects part of that effort. It reviews the results of a scientific testing program in a number of ports around Australia to assess the nature of organisms involved with ballast discharge and the dangers they may pose to our own marine life. I understand that the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service is also conducting research assessing the effectiveness of various chemical and physical methods, such as ultraviolet and heat treatment, of eliminating a range of marine organisms which may be present in ballast water.

For some time, the Australian Government has recognised the dangers to marine life from foreign organisms discharged in ships' ballast water. These problems are being addressed by the current intensive research program and active participation in international efforts to reduce this risk to our environment, fishing and aquiculture industries and human health.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I preface my question by referring to the Australia Wide approved deposit fund-investment fund which has given its unit holders only 21 days notice to consider whether the funds should be wound up and has not provided any alternatives to unit holders, such as the replacement of the existing trustees and managers. I ask the Minister: firstly, does the Government consider it fair or reasonable that investors, many of whom have almost certainly large potential losses, are only entitled to 21 days to consider whether the funds should be wound up, and have no automatic right to an independent review of their position and rights? Secondly, does he consider that a fund maintaining less than one per cent of its assets in liquid form has complied with former sections-now being renumbered-164 and 168 of the Companies Code concerning the maintenance of adequate buy-back facilities? Thirdly, what action, if any, will the Minister take to investigate whether these provisions have been breached by the Australia Wide approved deposit fund-investment fund?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the first question, I am advised that a 21-day notice period for the holding of a meeting of members of a fund of this kind is consistent with industry practice. I am also advised that investors in the Australia Wide approved deposit fund were, in fact, given approximately 28 days notice of the meeting, which is to be held on 19 August 1991.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand that the trustee of the fund, the Permanent Trustee Co. Ltd, had commissioned the accounting firm Duesburys to prepare an independent report on the state of the fund. That report was sent to fund members with the notice of meeting. I am further advised that the manager is of the view that it would be more advantageous to members that the fund be wound up in an orderly manner rather than continued. Duesburys has confirmed that the proposed course of action is fair and reasonable. I am also advised that all fund members will have the opportunity to speak at the meeting on 19 August. If for whatever reason they are not convinced that the course of action proposed by the fund manager is in their best interests, it will of course be open to them to vote against the proposal.

As to the second question, I am advised that the ASC has considered the matter and is of the view that there are no breaches of the relevant provisions of the Companies Act and codes and the corresponding provisions of the Corporation's law requiring the maintenance of adequate buy-back arrangements.

As to the last question, in the light of what I have just said, an investigation into the relevant provisions of the former and present legislation concerning buy-back arrangements would serve no purpose. However, I am advised that both the ASC and the ISC, which share regulatory responsibility in relation to approved deposit funds of this type, are monitoring the situation. Whether matters connected with the affairs of the fund warrant any action will be a matter for them to determine.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Can the Minister advise the Senate of the role played by the Australian trade union movement in the decision by the Toyota Motor Co. of Japan to build a massive new state of the art manufacturing plant at Altona, in the Melbourne metropolitan area, thereby expressing great confidence in the future of the Australian economy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether I should start this answer by saying, `Oh, what a feeling' and leap in the air.
—No.

—Well, I will not. Toyota Australia has, in the exercise of a great deal of confidence in the Australian economy and the future of the Australian car manufacturing industry, committed to a greenfield site in Altona, Victoria, an investment of $450m, which is a significant investment and the first phase of a coming and further investment in future manufacturing development for this industry. It is an investment which will create a huge number of new jobs and enable a state of the art car to be manufactured for export from Australia. It will bring to this economy a whole range of other skills that will stand us in good stead to develop the manufacturing focus that we have so earnestly required.

ANSWER.PARA: The question is: what contribution has the trade union movement made to this project? I think it is true that Toyota Australia would be the first to acknowledge that the ACTU, through its President, Martin Ferguson, has played an important, if not significant, role in encouraging the formation of one union for this greenfield site to have one bargaining unit and to follow through on a range of technological and award restructuring initiatives, which will make it efficient from a work practices and managerial practices point of view. It is an initiative, too, which will underpin this development by providing career pathing and training. So there will be an advancement in remuneration for employees not simply by service but by acquiring new and better qualifications.

This investment, which has the significance I have referred to, could not have gone ahead in the way in which it has unless those preconditions were met. It is important that Toyota has publicly acknowledged that. I think it is appropriate that Senator Maguire, coming from a car manufacturing State such as South Australia, should raise this question. It indicates the degree of flexibility that the unions have gone to under the amendments to create a more rationalised union structure, to encourage developments of this significance by rationalising union coverage, cutting out demarcation disputes, having one union and a more efficient enterprise based approach.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I note the Government's recent ban on the importation of pig embryos and genetic material due to the threat posed by mystery swine disease, which has devastated herds in Europe and North America. Given that the transmission mechanism of this disease is still unknown, would it not be prudent to also ban the importation of pork meat, especially as this disease has the effect of causing abortions in 90 per cent of pig embryos, and would, therefore, literally decimate the Australian pork industry if it took hold in this country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This question turns on whether it would be prudent-because of a ban on the importation of pig embryos-to ban the importation of pig meat. Senator O'Chee is courageous enough to express that it would be prudent. I am not so courageous, because I am not an expert on veterinary disease and the likely transmissibility of that disease in these circumstances. I rely on those who are expert, and in this case the expert is the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service.

ANSWER.PARA: In the case of the importation of pig meat, AQIS has, over a number of years, gone through a quite rigorous assessment, calling upon both academic and independent professional expertise to make an assessment as to the likely transmissibility of any disease by the importation of what is commonly regarded as Canadian pig meat, but which may be pig meat from other sources. The advice of the Quarantine and Inspection Service at this stage, as I recall it-I cannot be absolutely precise about this because I am now relying on my memory-is that, in certain circumstances, the importation of pig meat from abroad is acceptable in terms of what risk would be run for the transmissibility of diseases into the Australian market. I rely on that assessment, by the professionals best placed to make the judgment, as to likelihood.

I conclude by saying that there is a concern about whether these sorts of assessments ought to be used as a non-tariff barrier to trade. Among pig meat producers in Australia, there is-with due respect to them-an insistence that we should make more rigorous than is reasonable our veterinary assessments in order to prevent the free flow of trade.

Senator O'Chee and other honourable senators would know that we are committed to an open and transparent process in our assessments on the likelihood of disease transmissibility, and that we are committed to an open trading regime where we will not use as non-tariff barriers or other forms of hidden protection biological assessments or assessments of this nature. If there is any implication that we should perhaps use this for trade purposes, let me dispense with that suggestion immediately in saying that we will not do that; we will continue the open and transparent approach to disease assessment and risk management that we have used in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note Senator Cook's comment that he based his judgment on the assessment of various bodies; but, given that the transmission mechanism of mystery swine disease is unknown, how can those bodies say that the importation of pig meat poses no threat to the pig industry in this country? Given that, would it not be reasonable to consider the very real threat that would be posed to the Australian pork industry if this disease came in through the importation of meat? Given that the Government has already taken some steps, why will it not go the whole way?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know that any of the professionals in this field who make these assessments say categorically and absolutely beyond qualification that there is, to use Senator O'Chee's term, no threat. I think they say that the risk, likelihood or possibility of the transmission of disease is so infinitesimal as not to be able to be considered as reasonable for the purposes of making an assessment in these circumstances.
—Is it worth that risk?

—I am asked by way of interjection, `Is it worth it?'. One cannot say, for example, that in five minutes time there will not be an earthquake which will engulf this whole building and wipe out our population. The possibility of the transmission of this disease is of about that order that we are talking about. I cannot categorically say that there is no threat. There is always that possibility, but it is very unlikely-totally improbable. In the circumstances, if we were to give in to that possibility we would be seen by our international trading partners as using this as a mechanism to control trade.

ANSWER.PARA: For a National Party senator to raise this question is, I think, somewhat odd because what would happen-if not only on wheat and wool and other major commodities that we export-if other nations decided to do what we are being urged to do in relation to pigmeat and to those commodities and block our trade on major items on the trade budget?

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is the Minister aware that the United Nations is breaching its own status of women philosophies in regard to the number of women it appoints to the United Nations Secretariat? What action has Australia taken to draw attention to this double standard and to develop a strategy to ensure that women are more equitably represented at the United Nations? Does the Minister agree that more women would enhance the level of mediation and communication skills acknowledged as a special female characteristic and so vitally essential in UN negotiations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure about the sexist assumptions underlying the last part of the question, but as to the main part of it I can say this: I am aware that notwithstanding that the UN Charter enshrines the equal rights of men and women and their equal eligibility for service in the UN Secretariat, it does have a poor track record in advancing the status of women within in its ranks.

ANSWER.PARA: By December 1990 the UN had not achieved the relatively modest participation rate target for women of 30 per cent in senior policy and decision-making posts. We, as the Australian Government, have been concerned about this trend. We have continually called for greater efforts to advance the status of women in the UN Secretariat. The statement to the General Assembly in November 1990 on behalf of Canada, Australia and New Zealand by the Australian permanent representative to the UN, Dr Peter Wilenski, was particularly critical of the fact that, of the most senior 45 jobs in the Secretariat, only two were held by women.

Australia has taken a number of steps to help ensure that women are equitably represented in the upper echelons of the UN. At the forty-fifth session of the General Assembly we were closely involved in the drafting and adoption of resolutions which, among other things, urged the Secretary General by 1995 to increase to 35 per cent the number of women in senior policy and decision-making posts, to increase the number of women at senior levels, to identify the main obstacles to improvement in the status of women in the Secretariat, and to propose ways of overcoming those obstacles.

We co-sponsored a similar resolution at the UN Commission on the Status of Women in March 1991 and will continue to give high priority to improving the status of women in the UN during the forthcoming session of the General Assembly. We would welcome the applications of suitably qualified Australian women for senior positions in the UN and we will, of course, continue to regularly review the participation rate of women in UN bodies.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a question for the Minister for Industrial Relations. It therefore relates to the serious issue of the deal apparently done between Mr Hawke and the union movement to oblige the payment by employers to employees of superannuation of 6 per cent by 1993. How does the Government expect business, already gripped by a further decline in the economy-as evidenced in the national accounts figures brought down yesterday-to afford to pay this additional backroom deal? With a level of almost 10 per cent unemployment in this country, how many further jobs does the Government expect to be lost as a result of this additional impost?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think it is appropriate to make any assumptions about anything at this stage. Although a meeting did take place between the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Government yesterday, the Treasurer has indicated that he will address the question of legislative superannuation in the Budget, which is only four days away. I will not be drawn into giving any details or confirming any assumptions about matters that may be contained in the Budget in that respect.

ANSWER.PARA: As to business reaction to the prospect of some movement in this area, I think it should be acknowledged, as Senator Cook said, that that reaction has not been at all uniform. Mr Leon Daphne today supported the general thrust for increased superannuation and noted that workers over recent years had made genuine wage sacrifices and that real wage increases had been very well controlled. So consideration of any extension of this should be seen in the context not only of providing equitable retirement income for all workers, but also in the context of continuing wage restraint, which is of the essence in terms of the management of the economy as a whole and in terms of the likely outcomes that business needs and wants.

The business community can be reassured in this respect that the Government will continue with its reform agenda consistent with the general anti-inflationary strategy, which is central to that agenda at the moment. We are very mindful of the hard times that some sections of the business community have been experiencing and certainly we will be very closely considering the implications of any proposal in this area on the business sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications and relates particularly to the termination of employment today of the popular and well performed Tasmanian Australian Broadcasting Corporation newsreader Mr John Remess. For the many Tasmanian viewers who are puzzled by this event I ask: what criteria are used in the selection of ABC news readers; were these criteria used when a new news reading position was created in Hobart; what opportunities are there in staff development programs to enable existing ABC staff to acquire the skills which would satisfy these criteria and have these opportunities been made available to Hobart's existing news staff?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As an independent broadcaster, the ABC, as I have said on many occasions in this chamber, is responsible for its own management decisions, as it should be.

ANSWER.PARA: I have been advised that Mr Remess may lose his position as a result of a review of staffing arrangements. Mr Remess has a substantive position of announcer-television. Since 1985 he has occupied a position of compere-interviewer and has been the regular Monday to Friday television newsreader. A recent staffing review concluded that the position occupied by Mr Remess could be used more productively by appointing a person who could become involved in the production process as well. The position was subsequently classified as `Journalist-Presenter' and advertised in the press. Mr Remess was an unsuccessful candidate for the position. To address Senator Bell's question about the criteria, these included: a sound education, preferably at tertiary level; an excellent speaking voice and strong presentation skills; a self-starter with experience in television reporting, production and presenting; the ability to write links and news updates and compile field reports; the ability to interview talent and edit selected story material; the ability to work under pressure and to tight deadlines in a team environment, and a sound knowledge of local, inter-state and international news and current affairs. It is obvious from those criteria that no-one in the Opposition would have been successful in applying for the position.

I personally understand the angst that is no doubt felt by the loyal supporters of this person. I personally have lobbied the ABC, as I am sure many people in Australia have on previous occasions, in the Northern Territory when presenters have been changed. I happen to like early morning announcers who play a bit of decent music, give a time call and let us listen to the news rather than the ones who inflict us with their own allegedly hilarious opinions about every subject under the sun. I have lobbied the ABC in respect of changes it has made, as any person is entitled to.

I understand Senator Bell's position. I reiterate that it is not up to the Senate, or indeed the Government, to make management decisions of this nature for the ABC; it is in its province to do so. To answer the last part of Senator Bell's question, the ABC does provide a very wide range of in-house training for its staff.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Given that the national accounts figures released yesterday showed a household savings ratio for the June quarter of just 4.3 per cent, the lowest quarterly figure in the last 16 years, and as the current account deficit, in effect, represents the shortfall between saving and investment, what are the implications of this reduction for the future of the current account, especially given that the Government is dissaving by running a Budget deficit? What scope does the Minister see for achieving both an improved current account situation and greater investment when household savings are at such a record low?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As John Kerin, the Treasurer, said in his press conference yesterday:

ANSWER.PARA: The fact that we are dissaving at this part of the business cycle is to be expected and the whole farmer sector is dissaving and the economy in general dissaves, and that is as we come out of the recession people start saving again. But you can't expect savings given the recessionary situation we are in.

There is nothing particularly startling about those figures; they are just a corollary of the general situation that the economy has been confronting but which there is every reason to believe it will not be confronting any longer.

The news has been very good about the current account deficit over the last 12 months. The current account deficit has fallen by 30 per cent from $22.3 billion in 1989-90 to $15.7 billion in 1990-91. In that particular context, there is further good news in the national accounts figures about the future of the current account because of the information I relayed to Senator Vanstone yesterday-she obviously was not listening-about the growth in net exports and of export activity. Exports have been contributing very positively to activity in the June quarter, making a very substantial contribution to growth in the financial year as a whole, the highest contribution from the external sector in a financial year for nearly three decades.

The foundations are there for the completion of this process of recovery for the current account deficit. We would expect the savings situation to improve as the economy consolidates the recovery that is now manifestly under way.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What are the likely effects of the Inkathagate scandal on the process of negotiation in South Africa? How do the recent revelations affect the Minister's assessment of the situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The revelation that the South African Government has been engaged in secret funding of Inkatha, despite assurances to the contrary volunteered to me during my recent visit, has had a serious effect on the trustworthiness and the credibility of the South African Government in the eyes of most South Africans. It has also dealt a very considerable blow to the credibility of Chief Buthelezi's Inkatha Freedom Party, not to mention the handful of very vocal conservatives opposite who have consistently failed to assess the Inkatha movement in anything but ideological terms.

ANSWER.PARA: These latest revelations, although they are obviously unwelcome, come as no surprise to informed observers and confirm the evidence that, regrettably, Inkatha has been compromised by its association with the Government it purports to oppose.

Also of interest in the recent revelations is the admission by Foreign Minister, Pik Botha, that some $50m worth of assistance was provided to anti-SWAPO parties during the so-called free and fair elections in Namibia in 1990, which the South African Government was itself responsible for administering. This was at a time when, it will be remembered, the South African authorities were actually threatening to veto the involvement of Australian peace-keeping troops because of doubts concerning their partiality.

As serious as all these allegations about secret funding are in themselves, an even more urgent concern is the implications they hold for the persistent body of allegations and evidence that some elements of the police force have themselves been playing an active role in fomenting violence against the anti-apartheid movement, in collusion with Inkatha.

President de Klerk has, of course, moved in the last couple of weeks to try to diffuse the situation. Although denying personal knowledge of the payments, he has demoted his two chief security Ministers. He has also promised a partial review of the covert operations of the security forces and he has said that no further funding would be provided to political parties. On violence, he reiterated assurances that the security forces were not involved and promised that all allegations would be referred to a commission for investigation.

While the ANC has rejected these moves as inadequate in various ways, I think importantly, and to its credit, the ANC has nonetheless indicated a willingness to proceed with all-party negotiations, including with both the South African Government and Inkatha. It now appears that the first subject for discussion at those negotiations will be the need for some form of interim government to impartially manage the transition process. And I note in that respect that there have been some encouraging things said by President de Klerk in acknowledgment that the South African Government cannot be both referee and player in that process.

On balance, it is my view, and I believe the Government's view, that this funding scandal-and that is entirely an appropriate word for it-may end up actually doing a little more good than harm to the reform process in so far as it may contribute to levelling the playing field as between the major players.

We have a situation where the South African Cabinet has been recast in a more reformist mould, with the demotion of Ministers Vlock and Malan. It does create a situation which will obviously reduce the capacity of Inkatha to play a disruptive role in the future, should it be minded to do so. It creates a situation where the security forces are under very much closer rein and scrutiny than they have been in the past and it has, obviously, dealt something of a blow to the Government's confidence, which I think is no bad thing in terms of bringing it to the conference table in a slightly more measured and balanced way in the future than it has been so far. If it forces the Government to refocus its attention on finally fulfilling its commitments about political prisoners, exiles and so on, again, it will have been no bad thing at all.

In that respect, I want to welcome the announcement last night that the Government, the ANC and Inkatha have agreed on the question of violence on a five-point peace accord to be signed at a major conference scheduled to be held on 14 September. That peace accord flows from the successful church and business sponsored peace conference process that was under way in June and July. It involves a code of conduct for political parties and the security forces and it obviously represents a very considerable step forward.

Finally, Australia will continue to play its part in all of this by ensuring that a degree of international pressure is maintained, as appropriate, through all stages of the reform process, while acknowledging at the same time and rewarding, if you like, genuine progress through the phased easing of sanctions. It remains our policy to do just that.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister representing the Attorney-General relates to the alleged application of various statutory provisions to parliamentary inquiries. I refer the Minister to the opinion of the Attorney-General's Department of 20 August 1990, relating to sections 51 and 55 of the National Crime Authority Act; the opinion of the Attorney-General's Department of 13 April 1991, relating to section 67 of the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act; and the opinion of the Attorney-General's Department of 14 May 1990, relating to section 135a of the National Health Act 1953, all of which have been tabled by me in the Senate. I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that each of these opinions relates to the secrecy provisions of the relevant Act and each opinion disagrees or contradicts the other. I therefore ask the Minister: will he undertake to address the confused and contradictory views of the Attorney-General's Department? Will he provide the Senate with the considered and concluded view of this Government as to the relevance of the 300 secrecy provisions contained in the various Acts of the Commonwealth as they impinge upon the powers of the Senate and the committees of the Senate? While the Attorney-General is looking for the answer, perhaps I might remind him of an opinion given in 1985 by the then Attorney-General and the then Solicitor-General, which said--
—Order! I think you have asked your question.

—There is a little more to come. It is clear that parliamentary privilege is considered to be so valuable and essential to the workings of responsible government that express words in the statute are necessary before it may be taken away. As the Attorney-General looks through his brief, I ask whether the Government would be receptive to a private member's Bill which addressed, by way of a declaratory amendment, the question of the secrecy provisions.

—I am indebted to Senator Crichton-Browne for his courtesy in keeping his question going for long enough for me to find a reference to this matter. However, although there is a reference to the issue and although there are four appendices dealing with it and containing the full text of the opinions to which Senator Crichton-Browne referred, I am afraid there is no answer in the brief. —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the recently released study commission report of the Business Council of Australia entitled Avoiding Industrial Action? Does the report emphasise the need for an enterprise-based approach to employee relations? Does the report also emphasise the need for management practices in the workplace to change in order to encourage the development of a workplace environment more conducive to cooperation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the report and I welcome it. It is certainly an interesting and thoughtful contribution to the current debate. I compliment Professor Fred Hilmer of the University of New South Wales, the professional consulted by the Business Council, for this review. We now have considered views by the Confederation of Australian Industry and the BCA as to the future of the industrial relations system and how it might be structured. There is an important difference in their views: the Confederation of Australian Industry wishes the Industrial Relations Commission to be removed as a compulsory arbitration system and have it accessed by the parties on a strictly voluntary basis; whereas the Business Council of Australia sees real purpose and merit in maintaining the Commission in its present form, although making some alterations to the way in which unions and employers might access it for the purposes of certified agreements or, if you like, collectively bargained agreements.

ANSWER.PARA: This is the second in a series of publications by the Business Council; the first was about enterprise bargaining. I am a little disappointed by the title of this publication, the second in the series, which refers to avoiding industrial action. I would have thought that the real issue is how to remove lost time. Industrial action is just one element of removing lost time from industry. The other elements are: time lost through industrial accidents and disease; time lost through high staff turnover, which afflicts many Australian manufacturing companies in particular; and time lost through absenteeism. All these issues ought to be addressed in full.

In Australia we have a particular infatuation with only ever focusing on industrial disputes and not on the other areas of lost time. In some senses it is easier to focus on industrial disputes. In ranked order, it is the least offensive of the lost time elements because it talks about legal frameworks, things outside of the enterprise; whereas absenteeism, high labour turnover, accidents and disease talk about managerial changes and managerial operations within the enterprise. Thus, the blame always gets shifted to the legal framework without people spending sufficient time talking about how managers manage to reduce lost time in a particular enterprise.

For that reason I welcome many of the remarks made in this report about improving managerial expertise for a low dispute outcome or reducing lost time. Many of those remarks are very valuable, particularly coming from the Business Council. I certainly do not find offensive in any way the notion that Professor Hilmer articulates that, once an agreement has been reached, there ought to be a peace period for the life of that agreement. That is consistent with many of the things that happen now.

I do not think the report gives sufficient recognition to the fact that section 115 of the Federal Act provides a device now in which those forms of agreement can be taken through the Commission, and it does not require any amendment to the Act to do so. Professor Hilmer is trying to marry collective bargaining with compulsory arbitration. That is very difficult to do because he has tried to provide a version of slightly fettered, not entirely unfettered, collective bargaining and maintained all the penalties and legal devices while saying that this is somehow different from the present system. We are not quite yet at a situation in which industrial law in this country has been perfected to try to deal with the new focus that we are promoting for workplace bargaining.

This is a useful report. It now makes a significant contribution to the debate. The BCA has recognised that workers `cannot be made to do by compliance arrangements what cannot be achieved through commitment in a well managed business'. That is a significant comment by the Business Council because all too often with this matter we have a debate about improving the sanctions, upping the penalties and magnifying the fines, as if pains and penalties will bring about a better industrial relations outcome. We too infrequently talk about how one manages to develop an enterprise along a teamwork approach so that the penalties are a non-event. This report brings that out and many Opposition members ought to pay particular attention to that because they are the ones infatuated by the pains and penalties route.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: National Road Rules and Drivers Licences

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. In the light of the recent successful national road agreements from the Special Premiers Conference, will the Minister support a move at this time for national road rules and a national register of drivers licences so as to extend the benefits of federalism to many more Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is indeed a very good idea. I have been provided with the following advice by the Minister for Land Transport, Mr Brown: the agreements reached at the Special Premiers Conference will provide a legislative and institutional framework for national consistency and regulations and charging for heavy vehicles over 4.5 tonnes. Heads of government agreed that officials report to the next conference on the feasibility and desirability of including lighter vehicles in the national system. The issues raised by Senator Crowley will be examined in that context.

ANSWER.PARA: Implementation of a national heavy vehicle driver licensing scheme commenced this year, on 1 July. There is already significant uniformity in Australian road rules for vehicles in general. The national road code provides a basis for uniform road rules across Australia. There are, of course, still some notable exceptions, such as Victoria's different priority rules at intersections.

Austroads is currently undertaking a review of the national traffic code; a national demerit point exchange system has been finalised; and the Federal Government has long supported progress towards more consistent national arrangements, with differences only where they relate to the genuine requirements of the local operating environment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier in Question Time, Senator Crichton-Browne asked me about the secrecy provisions and parliamentary committees. I am now in a position to give him an answer. The Solicitor-General also said that the need for clarifying laws in this respect is obvious in the light of the need for clear guidance in legislation of the rights and duties of parliamentary committees and of officers of the Executive in such cases. TALK.START.PARA: —Order! In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901 I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Auditor-General's report No. 4, Comcare-Compensation payment operations; 1989-90 Financial Statement audit and 1989-90 Annual Report presentation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

Audit Report No. 4 of the Auditor-General is a very serious audit report, not simply because it involves a clear dispute with Comcare but because the matters raised by the Auditor-General are, in many instances, of some substance. In respect of one of the areas of disagreement, I am not quite certain whether it is a matter of almost lese-majeste for the Auditor-General, but it clearly involves the Auditor-General's anger with what seems to be the subject of some double dealing by Comcare, and it seems to be quite appropriate anger. Whether there is greater substance to it than the fact that the Auditor has been improperly dealt with will need another time to determine.
Going to the matters of substance, the key findings of the Auditor-General in this Audit Report No. 4 into Comcare are serious indeed. The Australian National Audit Office found that:
. . . a number of weaknesses in controls over payment operations exposed Comcare to risk of incorrect payment of compensation benefits and to undetected fraudulent claims.
The audit concluded:
. . . improvements were needed in the following areas:
-cross-checking of income received by recipients of compensation benefits from other Commonwealth agencies
-controls over the payment of medical accounts and the listing of medical providers
-review and quality assurance procedures, and
-controls over access to the computerised compensation processing system.

The Auditor does report that Comcare has taken or is proposing action on the majority of the Audit Office's findings and recommendations. In view of the large amounts of money involved, I hope that very serious attention is given to the comments by the Auditor-General, because the correction of weaknesses in controls over payment operations which expose Comcare to risk of incorrect payments and to undetected fraudulent claims are matters which should be given the highest priority.

I hope that perhaps the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) will come back to the Parliament and advise us as to what extent Comcare has corrected its activities. I can assure the Government that this matter will receive a great deal of attention at the upcoming Senate Estimates. As a result, I will not press it here because there are many other matters which honourable senators wish to raise this afternoon.

There is a real problem, however, which I would like to raise in the way Comcare appears to have set out to deceive the Auditor-General. That is a serious matter. I do not think the Auditor-General should be put in the position in which Comcare put him. The conclusion of the Auditor-General is:
. . . the effect of Comcare's presentation of the total set of financial information in its annual report-
that is, the 1989-90 annual report-
was to make Comcare's financial position unclear and to diminish the value to the Parliament of the Auditor-General's report on the financial statements.

That is a very serious comment from the Auditor-General. The Auditor-General takes the point that a set of management accounts was included in the annual report of Comcare; that those management accounts were presented before the Auditor-General's audited accounts, which were materially different; and that independent auditors from Price Waterhouse were asked to comment on the unaudited management accounts.

The report from Price Waterhouse did point out that these management accounts differ from the audited financial statements by considerable amounts. I will quote them to show how significant they are: a receivable $640.8m, being parliamentary appropriation expected to fund outstanding claims relating to incidents which occurred on or before 30 June 1989, was brought into account in the management accounts; investments were estimated at $154.6m, representing the premium funds deposited into Commonwealth consolidated revenue; and interest accrued on these investments estimated at $11.9m expected to be received in future years through parliamentary appropriations to fund claims incurred on or after 1 July 1989 was also included in the management accounts but by law is not to be included in the audited accounts.

Comcare may take the strong view that there was some merit in its outlining, one way or another, these amounts of expected incomes. If so, I have no disagreement with that. But I support the Auditor-General's view that it is misleading to put unaudited financial reports, called management accounts, at the front of the section dealing with the finances of Comcare, ahead of the financial statement audited by the Auditor-General. Naturally, the Auditor-General is fairly cross about this. He says:

As part of the responsibilities associated with the audit of financial statements, the external auditor is required to undertake a review of the documents containing the audited financial statements to determine whether other information in these documents is consistent with the audited financial information.
In other words, the auditor should look at all the other elements in the annual report to establish that they relate to the audited statement-he does not just add the figures. The report continues:

The ANAO adopts as policy, the requirements of Statement of Auditing Practice No 19-Other Information in Documents containing Audited Financial Statements . . . It is customary for the ANAO to receive from organisations whose financial statements the ANAO audits, a final draft copy of annual reports prior to printing so that the ANAO can comment in terms of AUP19-
the information on documents containing audited financial statements, loosely known as AUP19-
prior to finalisation of the audit opinion.
The report goes on:
Due to the protracted nature of the audit of Comcare's 1989-90 financial statements . . .

I should interpose that there was a great deal of difficulty and disagreement with the Auditor-General about some of the matters. It took a long time for those audited accounts to be resolved, particularly because of disagreement about the way in which Comcare had dealt with the liabilities of some off-budget agencies. In any event, the audit was of a protracted nature. Because of Comcare's wish to table its annual report early in the autumn session, ANAO said:

. . . on this occasion the ANAO agreed to provide an audit opinion prior to receiving a final draft copy of the annual report. On a number of occasions prior to issue of the audit opinion (and subsequently) the ANAO had requested a copy of the annual report prior to printing, however, no draft was provided.

As I understand it, the ANAO received the printed annual report on 21 February 1991 which was in fact the day that it was tabled in the Parliament. It clearly would have been printed before it was tabled in the Parliament. I notice, looking at the annual report itself, that, quaintly enough, there is no date on the letter from Sandy Halley, the Chairman and Chief Executive of Comcare, which is addressed to Senator the Hon. Peter Cook and which refers to Comcare's second annual report. I think that Comcare should smarten up its act. It should put a date on the letter in the future so that, apart from anything else, we could tell how long the report has been delayed in the Minister's office before it actually makes it to the Senate. We have found that some reports seem to take an awfully long time to get from the Minister's office to the chamber.

In any event, there is no doubt that the absence of a date here does not change the fact that the report could not have been printed, delivered to the Minister's office and tabled in the Senate on the same day. Yet it was not until the report was tabled that the Audit Office was given a copy of the remainder of the report, apart from the financial statements which it had audited. That, of course, is in total breach of the understanding and normal forms of behaviour of governmental bodies.

At the time that the Audit Office received the printed annual report on 21 February-the day of tabling-it undertook a review of the report in accordance with the requirements of AUP19. It observed that:

. . . separate management accounts had been included in the annual report preceding the audited statutory financial statements. The management accounts were supported by an expert comment from a partner in a firm of Chartered Accountants. The ANAO is concerned that an expert comment, which can be interpreted as a form of independent reassurance, was included with the management accounts, and that they were located in the annual report in front of the formal financial statements.
4.3.5 The ANAO considers that this ordering of the financial reports has the effect of reducing the value to readers of the audited financial statements and the audit opinion thereon.
4.3.6 In addition, the management accounts were not annotated sufficiently clearly to indicate that they had not been subject to a formal, independent audit.

4.3.7 In the ANAO's view, the overall impact of Comcare's presentation of the financial information in its annual report is to make Comcare's financial position unclear and to diminish the value to the Parliament of the Auditor-General's report.

Amen to all of that. I would now like to see Comcare respond to this Parliament about the comments made by the Auditor-General. I think it is up to Comcare to make such a response. If it does not want to make a response to the Parliament, I invite it to make a response to me as I brought the matter up. I stress that it is not simply a question of the Auditor-General having his nose put slightly out of joint by receiving the audited accounts after the unaudited financial statement. I look forward to pursuing this matter in the forthcoming Senate Estimates committee hearings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Baume said that much of the material involved in this matter will be taken up at Senate Estimates. I want to deal with the way in which claims are sometimes treated. Comcare is a great scheme. Its intent is to protect people whose income would otherwise be rendered nil because of injuries they have received in the course of their work. It protects everybody who works for the Commonwealth. In fact, it goes further than that. It protects people who work for Telecom, and I will come to that in a minute.

SPEECH.PARA: I say in passing that the proper way of looking after not only people who work for the Commonwealth but also those who work for any employer is, first of all, to ensure that injury does not occur in the first place; that is the humane way of approaching the matter. It saves a lot of anguish and social problems if people are not injured in the first place. As a secondary consideration, it makes the whole thing cheaper in any event because money does not have to be paid out. Unfortunately, people do get injured and they must be compensated.

As I say, the scheme is a good one. It is appropriate-and this was the thrust of Senator Baume's address-that the scheme be conducted properly. I have had some representations made to me about the way in which it is administered at times, particularly by Telecom. Telecom is, in effect, a self-insurer in this area. I have been told, and have had it confirmed by a lawyer who acted for the source of the information, that at times Telecom refuses to pay entitlements and demands that a person injured in its employ supply information to it to which it is not entitled before it will do so. I will give one illustration of that point and finish. Apparently, the case I refer to is typical of many.

A person was injured while working for Telecom and Telecom admitted liability for that injury, which meant it had to pay. In fact, it did pay. After some time, Telecom asked the person, whose claim it had accepted, for his and his wife's income tax returns, not for any period from the time of the injury onwards but for the time before. It was quite a wrong request, particularly in respect of the man's wife, and it went against the general thrust of what we have legislated for in terms of privacy. It was pointed out to Telecom that it was quite wrong, but this made absolutely no difference. Telecom kept insisting on the returns and delayed this person's payment for some months. In my view, that was quite outrageous, given the fact that people who are injured not only have to bear the physical and mental pain that that brings but also the anxiety of not knowing where their money is to come from.

After all, this scheme, like many others that have been set up, is to protect workers who give their all for employers. It is incumbent on employers in that situation to make sure that people who are injured in their employ are treated properly. When that does not happen, particularly in a company such as Telecom, it is a matter for comment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Auditor-General's report No. 5, Department of Social Security-Family Allowance Supplement-Income and Assets Testing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

The latest Auditor-General's report again demonstrates that the Department of Social Security is not the trim, taught and efficient department the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) likes to claim. Let me remind the Senate that last December the Auditor-General found that 20 per cent of telephone rental concession payments were made to people who were not eligible for them. In June, he found that 85 per cent of pensioner valued real estate-excluding the family home-was undervalued and the average undervaluation was $61,224.

Now the Auditor-General has found that while the family allowance program operates efficiently and effectively for the majority of its beneficiaries, in certain circumstances families can continue receiving assistance for considerable periods after significant increases in their income. Specific observations were made as follows: there is a high margin of error allowed for estimates of income in which a tax assessment for the previous year has not been provided; the conditions prescribing those change of circumstances which must be notified to the Department of Social Security are resulting in beneficiaries with similar circumstances being treated differently; and, due to work pressures and current reassessment provisions, some DSS officers are not investigating identified possible overpayments. The Audit Office has recommended that DSS review its current allowable margin for error when unsubstantiated income estimates are made by DSS clients. It also recommended that DSS review its current notification and assessment procedures for the family allowance supplement.

In its response to the Auditor-General's recommendations the Department has stated, as it usually does with these reports, that it is tied by legislation and Government policy decisions. We see almost a Wimbledon replay with the ball going backwards and forwards across the court-from the Minister to the Department.

As for the telephone rental concession and the pensioner assets test concerns, responsibility for proving the efficiency of this latest program has been thrown back fairly and squarely into the court of the Minister by his Department. Whether or not he will see fit to act is debatable, given his recent claim that `There is not one other way now I can shave money off the social security budget'. That was before the telephone rental concession payments and the other issue about the valuation of properties had come into view.
However, in view of this perennial responsibility swapping between the Department and its Minister, it is pertinent to quote from page 4 of this report, where the Auditor-General says:

If every procedure which was the object of ministerial or legislative consideration were, by this means, to be regarded no longer as `procedure' but as `Government policy' and thereby put beyond the ambit of the ANAO the action by the Government and the Parliament in establishing an efficiency audit capability could be nullified.
That is a very sobering comment made by the Auditor-General. I think it is something the Senate ought to consider very seriously.

Of course, by far the most productive thing Minister Richardson could do to reduce social security expenditure is to convince his Cabinet colleagues to undertake the necessary economic, taxation and industrial relations reform which this country needs desperately and is crying out for. The figures we saw yesterday are a perfect example of this. Regardless of the way Minister Evans answered questions in Question Time yesterday, I think he has been to the Keating school of grooming and learning how to make good news bad news.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good, I succeeded.

—No, the Minister did not do very well. In fact, I think Mr Keating would have given him about three out of 10. Mr Keating always used to sit up and tell us, `These figures were good; their effervescence is just a bubbling over of the champagne in the glass'. The Minister will have to improve if he is going to do as well as Mr Keating in making bad news good. If the Minister wants to correct the situation and reduce expenditure on social security, then he ought to convince his Cabinet colleagues to look to the reforms that we desperately need in this country before we spiral even further into the mess and down the Argentinean road to the banana republic Mr Keating predicted some time ago. We need to have those reforms and then at least we will be able to address some of these issues without having to concentrate also on dealing with the spiralling increase in the number of people requiring family allowance.

SPEECH.PARA: Putting aside the 700,000 unemployment beneficiaries and their families, the Minister must also recognise that he has a responsibility to get his Department running in the most efficient manner possible, despite the fact that there are so many families currently requiring social security. Whilst I admit that the Auditor-General has stated that the scope for overpayments of fraud in this particular case is small, his latest report is but another addition to the plethora of departmental inefficiencies that have surfaced over the last 12 months, and I referred to two of them earlier.
In conclusion, I remind the Senate of a quote from the Minister when he was attempting to stave off the Expenditure Review Committee earlier this year. On ABC radio on 22 March he claimed:
There's no question now that after five or six years of systematically going through social security expenditure to make sure that it's properly targeted-
and now to an increasing number, as I have just pointed out-
that if you want to get any significant savings out of social security you've got to take it out of the pockets of the poor.

That is nonsense. Here is another Auditor-General's report telling us exactly the same thing. The way we can increase social security for people is to take them off social security by creating jobs and wealth for them by proper reforms, and also by trimming the Department of Social Security, which is constantly seen in situations where it could do better.

This latest report from the Auditor-General shows that the Minister is flying with the fairies-I do not know which fairies; maybe the ones on my left-hand side-if he believes that his Department is the lean, mean fighting machine that he likes to claim it is. This Auditor-General's report demonstrates yet again that some reforms could take place in the Department itself to ensure that the money that is there can be directed and targeted to those who are in genuine need.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
