DEBATE.TITLE: INTERSTATE ROAD TRANSPORT AMENDMENT BILL 1991INTERSTATE ROAD TRANSPORT CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1991

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —When Question Time interrupted my speech today I was about to make a point, but before I do, Mr Acting Deputy President, you will excuse me if I recognise someone in the gallery from my home town in Western Australia?
—Certainly.
—Incidentally, my mother tells me we were born in the same hospital on the same day.

SPEECH.PARA: Getting back to the point I was about to make, this Bill, which amends the Interstate Road Transport Charge Act 1985, will remove the provision which permits only the cost of road maintenance to be taken into account when determining those registration charges and limits the registration charges that can be imposed on vehicles registered under that system; that is, the federal interstate registration scheme. The amendments will enable the determination, under the FIRS, of registration charges on the basis of full cost recovery, taking into account construction and maintenance costs. Under the principal Act only maintenance could be recovered. Initially this was included on the basis of section 92 of the Constitution. The reinterpretation of section 92 of the Constitution by the High Court of Australia in 1988 means that the construction costs can now be taken into account when setting FIRS charges.

The point I was making before the lunch suspension was that the then Minister for Transport and Communications attended the Yass transport blockade in 1988 and promised the truckies that we would never have full cost recovery, including construction of roads. I suppose that promise was made three years ago and we can excuse Senator Evans, who was the Minister for Transport and Communications at the time, but I thought it would last a bit longer than it did.

However, most States already take some construction costs into account in their registration charges. The introduction of the Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill means that B-doubles will be fully cost-recovered. Charges for other categories under the old system-FIRS-will not change at this time. So charging for B-doubles was not to be considered; however, I believe it was considered at the Special Premiers Conference held in July, but no definite proposition came out of that.

Taking the B-doubles out of the entire charging regime means they will be put on their own. As I said this morning, using B-doubles results in at least a 20 per cent efficiency, but the drivers will pay for that through extra charges. Of course, this adds to the ad hoc system that this Government has, and probably successive governments will have, when charging for road registration and that sort of thing. The industry argues that it already more than covers the cost of the roads it uses since it pays three and a half times as much tax as any other industry. That is according to the Inter-State Commission report on road user charging and vehicle registration. That report recommends that any review of charging should be done in the context of a review of the total tax burden.

Given the political net gains to the economy of the uniform introduction of B-doubles, it is unreasonable to expect the industry alone to pay the full cost of construction. Lighter vehicles use the roads as well and the transport industry should be charged for only the private benefit it receives from having roads constructed to carry the heavy vehicles; it should not be charged for the full cost recovery of construction.

Earlier I mentioned the fact that B-doubles improve the efficiency by 20 per cent. Initially that figure is 40 per cent, but it is brought back down to 20 per cent because the B-doubles, for some reason, are dearer to buy. I believe that is because they are an innovation new to Australia-New Zealand has had them for 15 years and America has probably had them for a lot longer-and so manufacturers tend, and feel entitled, to charge a bit more. Having had a look at the construction of the B-double trailers, I believe that in the short term it will be reduced so that somewhere near the full 40 per cent of extra efficiency will be gained.

Returning to road construction, as I said, I believe that not only heavy vehicles should have to carry that burden, but also all other vehicles. If there is anything over to cover the cars and lighter vehicles that are not paying for it, it should belong to the whole community.

However, I believe that this system of charging uses double standards. For instance, now that we have pulled the B-doubles out of general registration, under the new system the prime mover has to be licensed. That same prime mover can be used, and I am sure it will be used, because if we want to make full use of the system, we cannot always use B-doubles. At present, B-doubles are restricted to certain routes and places. It means that, if that vehicle is to be used anywhere else, there must be a return to the standard procedure of registration when the higher registration fee has already been paid. That is something that I will be bringing up in the committee stage.

I believe that if there is a special higher charging on B-doubles then any productivity gain-and this legislation was introduced to fix up the problems experienced in Victoria-will not go back to the freight users; it will go back to the Government to prop up the rail system as this Government, and probably other governments, have been doing for some time.

I wish to make a few general points relating to the transport situation. Treasury estimates that the transport industry pays $1 billion alone in sales tax. This does not include tax on fuel, stamp duty, company tax, payroll tax and income tax. In a speech to the Transport Association-I cannot place exactly where-the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) admitted that the road transport industry pays 3 1/2 times more tax than other industries. What is more, the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) agreed with him, but he has done nothing about it. That means that industries that rely on transport are taxed through the back door.

In agriculture alone, 10 per cent of the value of production is consumed in road transport for the average producer in Australia. In the remote areas-such as the area I farm myself-25 per cent of total income from the wheat crop goes on transport. I have had an argument on that matter with the Western Australian Government for at least 10 or 12 years, and over the years we have been able to do something towards lessening that problem. At the extreme end we have been paying $25 to $27 a tonne to shift wheat over a distance of about 400 kilometres, whereas in America, for the same number of dollars per tonne it could be shifted three times further, and be hauled through the Rockies as well.
The coalition's proposed goods and services tax, which will do away with sales tax, and other measures for improving the tax system will help the road transport industry as well.

In winding up, I believe that the road transport system in Australia is certainly over taxed. I believe that this Bill does very little to help that. As I said earlier, I support the idea of bringing in the B-doubles, which is the main part of Bill. We were forced to bring them in-the fact is that Victoria would not play ball. It was recommended by the Inter-State Commission's report on grain handling and storage quite some years ago and very little was done about it. I certainly welcome the Bill, but I do not welcome the charging system. We will be moving some amendments in the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill 1991 and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill 1991, I believe it is fair to say that this is the first major reform in the transport industry. Hopefully, the next ones will come quicker than this one.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to highlight briefly the advantages of using B-doubles and of reform in the road transport industry. My State, Western Australia, has been using larger configurations of trucks for transport for a number of years, with very startling results in efficiency gains and keeping the cost of transport down. I will address the benefits of B-doubles under the Federal interstate registration scheme.

B-doubles will operate right around the mainland, which will stop some of the wasteful practices which have been occurring on State borders. In fact, it has been brought to my attention that in some instances there have been delays of up to 14 hours for trucks seeking to get across the border into the next State. B-doubles have a pay load of 37 tonnes, which is a significant increase on the conventional 26 tonnes. As outlined by my colleagues, the productivity gains are in the order of 40 per cent but, after allowing for increased capital costs, that comes back to about a 20 per cent efficiency gain. As my colleague Senator Panizza said, as the B-doubles develop, I am quite certain that that efficiency gain will be even greater.

There will be a number of other benefits. First of all, consumers will benefit, which is very important. Also, particularly in light of the national accounts figures which came out yesterday, our exporters will benefit. The savings in the first year are estimated at about $250m, so that poses this question to the Government: why has it taken six years to introduce the recommendations of the National Association of Australian State Road Authorities? In talking to these two Bills before us, I emphasise that we cannot hang around for another six years before we have further reform in the road transport industry, or the transport industry in general.

However, there needs to be flexibility with or tolerance of unintended overloading. The best example I can give here is that of loading grain. Because of the nature of the product, there needs to be an estimation made in picking it up initially and there needs to be some understanding and tolerance. These trucks, by their very nature and because of the way they operate, cause less road wear. They are safer; there are fewer trucks on the road; and, because there is a greater pay load, speed is not necessary for the business to survive. I particularly urge the Australian Democrats to support our amendments with regard to making the registration fees consistent with those for other modes of transport.

TALK.START.PARA: —They want to add taxes, not take them off.

—Yes, I realise that, but maybe this time they will come to their senses. If we are going to maximise the efficiency gains that are available here, it is very important that charges be consistent. I am greatly concerned with what is happening in the transport industry. Charging procedures being put in place for the road transport industry are being made in such a way that they allow rail to compete with the road transport industry, rather than tackle the inefficiencies which exist within the rail system, making it more efficient so that it can compete.

SPEECH.PARA: One can refer to work practices and a whole range of other things, but one point I particularly emphasise is the fuel excise that the rail system pays on diesel. Initially about a third of the excise goes to road funding, and yet we never see too many trains trundling down a road. It has always seemed to me to be an anomaly that the rail system has to pick up some of the cost of road maintenance and road building in this country. The emphasis has to be not on making road transport dearer so that rail can compete, but on getting the inefficiencies out of the rail system so that there is fair competition between the two modes.

I will touch on a few of the charges to the rail system. These figures have been given to me by the National Transport Federation. I will highlight them. The road transport industry pays 35 per cent more in taxes and charges than the average paid by other industries. The purchase of an articulated unit-prime mover and trailer-and its travel of 250,000 kilometres per year in the first year contribute $84,750 in transport-related taxes and charges, these being as follows. A sales tax on the vehicle at 20 per cent is $37,600. Registration is $4,000. The fuel levy, State and Federal, is $41,900. The sales tax on tyres is 20 per cent, which equals $1,250. The sales tax on commercial vehicles is 17 1/2 per cent higher than the average of that on all goods in Australia. The import duties on commercial vehicles are 17 1/2 per cent higher than those on all goods in Australia.

We can see from those figures that the road transport industry is put at a significant disadvantage when compared with other industries. If we look at the transport business financial structures, we will find that, of the total cost, fuel comprises 35 per cent, wages 25 per cent, parts and overheads 35 per cent, with a gross profit under the current pricing structure of 5 per cent, making a total of 100 per cent.

All users of fuel pay 24.9 cents per litre. Of that 24.9 cents of the Federal fuel levy, only 5.8 cents per litre is returned to the roads. On those figures, an articulated vehicle travelling 250,000 kilometres a year which uses 140,000 litres of fuel would contribute $40,700, of which only $8,120 would be returned to roads. It is quite nonsensical to say that the road transport industry is not making its contribution in taxation. In fact, there is a very good case for the reform of the taxation system which we intend to introduce after the next election.

I conclude by saying that we on this side of the chamber support this Bill. We require it to be amended so that there is consistency in charges for licences. Once again, I strongly urge the Democrats to support our amendment so that we can maximise the potential efficiency gains in this reform.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill. The main provision of the Interstate Road Transport Bill regulates the maximum road mass and the maximum external limit of each vehicle and allows B-doubles to operate on Federal roads in spite of any State or Territory law to the contrary. However, there is an additional clause which allows the Minister to determine that certain roads are to be deemed Federal routes and, therefore, allow B-doubles to operate on those roads.

SPEECH.PARA: The Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills had some concerns about these determinations and drew attention to the fact that they may be considered an inappropriate delegation of legislative power. The Opposition introduced an amendment into the House of Representatives to rectify this matter by requiring the determinations made on roads and conditions to be tabled in both Houses of Parliament and subject to disallowance. The Government has already indicated that it will be accepting this amendment, but this is yet another instance-these are all too frequent-of slipshod and hasty drafting by this Government. The coalition is now supporting this Bill with amendments because it is hoped that it will improve efficiency on the roads, reduce costs to consumers and help people who live away from the major capital cities.

The second reading speech on this Bill makes fascinating reading. The Government is desperately trying to salvage some shreds of respectability in transport reform. It claims that it is actively pursuing a program of reform in land transport complementary to reforms already under way in the coastal shipping, waterfront and aviation sectors.

Despite the long list of enterprise agreements that the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) in Question Time yesterday claimed were being implemented, we await with breathless expectation for real reform on the waterfront with its escalating cost in idle time, a cost which has to be borne by somebody: the user in increased freight rates and ultimately the producer of goods who is trying to keep costs down and to remain competitive. There is no reform until there are reduced costs. The Conaust managing director, Richard Setchell, has said very bluntly:

The reform process is only about 10 per cent completed and if the last few weeks of union negotiations on our other enterprise agreements are any indication we will be at it until Christmas-not this Christmas, but Christmas 1995.
So much for reform on the waterfront! Let us hope that the land transport reforms will be a little more effective, but I doubt it. The second reading speech goes on to say:

The Federal Government recognises the considerable productivity, safety and environmental benefits offered by B-doubles. The introduction of B-doubles on a national basis is therefore an integral part of the Government's reform strategy.

There is no doubt that these vehicles are productive, because they have a payload of 37 tonnes compared with a conventional articulated vehicle with a payload of 26 tonnes. This adds a productivity gain of 40 per cent. Taking the higher capital and running costs into account, the Minister claims an efficiency improvement of 20 per cent and expects that these gains will be passed on to users in terms of lower freight charges.

The Minister claims that they are safer because they are estimated to have a 25 per cent higher roll-over limit than conventional articulated vehicles. The safety aspect of these vehicles has really not been extensively investigated. The Inter-State Commission makes only a brief reference in its report to safety concerns. Probably the greatest contribution that B-doubles make to safety is their large capacity, which means fewer vehicles are conveying the same load.

While the coalition supports the Bill with certain reservations, we will not support the Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill. The principal Act permits only road maintenance costs to be taken into account in determining charges for B-double combinations. It limits the charges that can be imposed on vehicles registered under the Federal interstate registration scheme.

The purpose of the Bill is to permit the cost of road construction to be taken into account in determining the level of charges. The Federal interstate registration scheme was first introduced because of difficulties arising from State imposed registration fees on trucks which did not cover the damage caused to roads. In 1954 the Hughes and Vale case relating to section 92 resulted in a High Court ruling that States could not impose taxes on trucks because it would contravene section 92, which provided that commerce and trade between the States would be absolutely free and, therefore, the Federal Government could not levy an impost on interstate trucks.

However, the court also ruled that States could impose charges on trucks but only as they related to damage to the roads. Hence, the road maintenance tax could be directly linked to the funding of road maintenance works. In 1979 the green dog truck blockade on the Razorback section of the Hume Highway successfully blackmailed the Wran Labor Government in New South Wales into abolishing these charges, and the other States caved in as well.

The Commonwealth needed some kind of charge imposed on trucks for road damage. As a result, the Federal interstate registration scheme came into being. Under the scheme the Federal charges related only to road damage and were not particularly high. Interstate trucks were free to register under a State scheme or the Federal scheme. Despite the fact that some State charges were very low, the Federal interstate registration scheme was still attractive to some State truck operators because there were no stamp duties and higher load limits were allowed.

It must be emphasised that the Federal charges still relate to road damage only. There was still no criterion whereby the Commonwealth could impose full cost recovery for roads which had to be designed and constructed for the use of heavy vehicle traffic.

In 1988 there was another case relating to section 92-Cole v. Whitfield. The High Court ruled in this case that section 92 had to do with discrimination between interstate and intrastate charges. By extension of these findings, charges could be imposed on interstate vehicles, provided that they were also imposed on intrastate trucks.

Since the 1988 interpretation of section 92, the Commonwealth has been in a position to levy charges to recoup the cost of road construction. Under FIRS the Commonwealth can now charge registration fees to recover the capital cost of road construction as well as road damage costs.

However, the Federal Government is playing a double game with these Bills. It is not prepared to recoup full cost recovery from all trucks, but it is using B-doubles as an identifiable group of trucks which have been operating for a comparatively short time on our roads. The levy fee on B-doubles will be aimed at full cost recovery. The Government, therefore, has at this time created a distinction between B-doubles and all other trucks.

The Opposition does not support this Bill for a number of reasons, especially the one raised by the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. The Committee noted that the explanatory memorandum to the Bill offered no justification for the removal of the limits on the charge. It also noted that the second reading speech indicates that the purpose of the Bill is to enable registration charges to be determined on a full cost recovery basis. Yet the Government admits that it is full cost recovery for one kind of vehicle only. The charges are not revealed in the legislation, but they will be set by regulation.

The Scrutiny of Bills Committee argued that the charges should be set by primary legislation and be subject to full parliamentary scrutiny. The Committee suggested that it was inappropriate to set such charges by regulation, particularly in the absence of any limits on the charges which could be set. I quote from the Minister's response to these concerns:

Registration of vehicles involved in interstate trade and commerce under the Federal Interstate Registration Scheme is an alternative to State registration. To set charges which are far in excess of State registration charges would be counterproductive since operators would merely maintain State registration. Charges set under the Charge Act will be consistent with charges presently being paid by B-doubles operating interstate in eastern Australia. In the circumstances I do not believe that there is a need to set maximum levels of charges for the purposes of this legislation.

Neither the Committee nor the Opposition is at all satisfied with this response. The argument seems to rely on the level of charges set by the States. The Committee argues that Commonwealth charges set in reference to State charges is an abrogation of power by the Commonwealth Parliament. It is clear that B-doubles are being used as a stooge by the Commonwealth Government to raise money for the deplorable roads in Australia. Over 55 per cent of our major roads have pavements which are at least 20 years old, yet only 2 per cent are being reconstructed each year. We are neither maintaining nor replacing our roads at an adequate rate.

Poor roads also force up the operating costs of interstate transport and commercial travel costs. It has been estimated that the annual cost per road freight vehicle is increased by up to $40,000 due to the condition of our road system. Conversely, road freight vehicles do add to the cost of our roads. The damage to roads caused by a fully-laden semi-trailer compared with the damage caused by a car is several thousand times greater. That is an argument for imposing charges on trucks for the use of our roads, but not for discriminating against one class of heavy vehicle.

There is no doubt that we need a better road system. Good roads save lives; they reduce fuel consumption; they cut labour and maintenance costs; they improve the basic infrastructure of the nation; and they reduce travelling time. In addition, they stimulate tourism and investment, create jobs and save tax dollars. We have a desperate need for high quality roads linking important Australian ports and terminals and cities. Only then can our exports become more competitive internationally. But this should be done by using more road tax dollars and fuel excises and not by discriminatory road charges. The Opposition does not support this Bill because it is discriminatory and because of the anomaly of setting the charges by regulation with an unknown limit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My colleagues have clearly and in some detail explained what the Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill 1991 and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill 1991 are all about. The Interstate Road Transport Act is amended by the first of these Bills, which provides for registration and regulation of prime movers and trailers. The second Bill amends the same principal Act, allowing charges on B-doubles to include recovery and construction costs as well as maintenance costs. Previously, a provision had existed in the Act which permitted only maintenance costs to be taken into account and which limited registration charges to that. This Bill removes those provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: As has been mentioned, the coalition supports the first Bill as we recognise that for some time there has been a need to allow B-doubles to operate over mainland Australia. This will improve our efficiency, give consumers a better deal, reduce road damage costs and assist people living in more remote parts of Australia with cheaper transport. I point out, as has been mentioned by my colleagues, that the Government's considerable delay in bringing these decisions to fruition has cost the nation approximately $1 billion.

Most of us have known of the benefits of B-double trucks for a considerable time. Their payload of 37 tonnes compares favourably with that of conventional articulated vehicles and, in fact, gives a productivity gain of about 40 per cent. If one takes into account the additional capital costs, the operational efficiency improvements are in the order of 20 per cent and, of course, cheaper transport means cheaper goods prices to consumers. Also, the damage to the roads is less. The safety record of these particular vehicles, which has been mentioned at length by my colleagues, indicates that they will help to make our roads much safer. Freight is finite and because we are using bigger payloads there will be fewer trucks on the road.

Senator Kernot made a comment which I could not quite understand. She was saying that we should be legislating to get vehicles off the road because it would then reduce emissions that interfere with the ozone layer, but Senator Kernot then went on to say that she opposed this Bill. This Bill, by increasing the payload that can be drawn by a single prime mover, is one step in the direction of having less motor vehicles emitting gases that can harm our environment. Senator Kernot and the Democrats in their typical fashion seem to have overlooked that.

TALK.START.PARA: —They hate truckies.
—They certainly do. That is also evidenced by the proposals in the Democrats' alternative Budget to tax road transport out of existence. I might come to that a little later.

SPEECH.PARA: When talking about safety, I am concerned that those trucks do take a little longer to pass. If one is driving on these privileged roads around Canberra, between Sydney and Melbourne or even between Sydney and Brisbane, one is able to find passing lanes-and quite often double lanes-where one can pass these huge vehicles but, if one drives on the roads where I drive, in north Queensland, these vehicles create some problems. It is very difficult to pass even a Laser, let alone a double-articulated vehicle such as these are. The Government owes it to those Australians living in the more remote areas to make the roads safer so that these trucks and every other vehicle using the roadways can expect some of the safety that is available to those who, as I say, drive on these privileged roads around Canberra, Sydney and Melbourne.

In respect of the second Bill, we will be moving an amendment which will ensure that the Government does not proceed with the provision to charge B-doubles differently from other vehicles. In the light of the 1988 High Court decision, this provision effectively determined registration costs taking into account road construction as well as maintenance. The legislation allows for this to be incorporated into the charging regimes for B-doubles but not for other vehicles. We believe that this is inappropriate, given that it will only act as a disincentive for operators contemplating the use of B-doubles.

However, in a sense, this legislation becomes irrelevant in the light of the decision of the Special Premiers Conference to get rid of the FIR scheme, or encompass it in the national heavy vehicle scheme. In spite of that, the Government has brought this legislation in to ensure a swift introduction to the national use of B-doubles and the coalition, of course, supports this move. As I understand it, the legislation was brought in mainly to overcome the difficulties being experienced in Victoria, where the Victorian ALP Government was too gutless to take the action which needed to be taken in that State to allow B-doubles simply because it did not want to offend its mates in the railway unions. To overcome that, we have had to bring in this Bill.

The concerns we have about the different charging arrangements are strengthened by the decision announced at the Premiers Conference under which B-doubles are again excluded from the timetable of a nationally consistent scheme. We do want to know from the Premiers Conference when these charges will be coming in, and that is what our amendment seeks to rectify. We see no reason why there needs to be any disparity between the registration charge regime for B-doubles and that for any other heavy vehicles. It seems quite ludicrous that the Government wants to propose a situation where charges paid by the B-double operators are higher than those paid by their competitors who are using smaller articulated and other trucks.

It is consistent with the Government's other actions in relation to road user charges which continually cause anxiety, particularly in provincial and rural Australia. These anxieties were only heightened by the recent Special Premiers Conference. All that the operators in rural and provincial Queensland know is that they face large registration charges increases to an extent to which no-one seems able to give a straight answer. They know that Mr Goss signed the intergovernmental agreement establishing the national heavy vehicle registration scheme only after Queensland was put in a so-called low cost zone with Western Australia and South Australia. Yet Mr Goss can shed no light whatsoever on what difference operators in Queensland will experience in comparison with their counterparts in southern States. He can give no indication whatsoever, except to say that the charges in Queensland will be lower.

Transport industry sources have said that the increases being contemplated amount to about a 400 per cent increase in registration charges and that States, such as Queensland, in the low cost zone can expect a charges increase of 5 per cent less than that. That is of great benefit to those of us in Queensland-instead of having the 400 per cent increase we now only have a 395 per cent increase! I hope for the sake of Queensland that those rumours are not true, and I hope that Mr Goss can assure transport operators that this is not the case.

I also hope that he is be able to spell out what he expects the level of charges increase to be, and what level he is willing to accept. In all the post mortems of the Premiers Conference, all that Mr Goss has been willing to say-or, perhaps, is even capable of saying-is that he has won a major concession for Queensland truckies. His rhetoric is not backed up by any indication on his part as to what he believes the charges increases will be and what he is prepared to accept. He can give no indication whatsoever.

Mr Goss has tried to allay fears by saying that he will veto any increases in charges which are too extreme and which will hurt country areas in Queensland. But the onus is really on Mr Goss to come clean with Queensland's road transport industry and spell out publicly just what sort of registration charges increases he is willing to wear before he uses his veto power. Transport operators have been left completely in the dark. They are very concerned, to put it mildly, and they would like some answers.

What Queensland operators do know, however, is that the Northern Territory Government refused to sign the agreement on the grounds that it would not be party to charges increases under consideration. So we might well ask: why did Mr Goss sign? Mr Goss is quoted in the following article from the Rockhampton Morning Bulletin:

the planned national system would mean heavy registration charges, spelling increased costs for rural areas . . . ``While the idea of a national heavy vehicle system is fine in terms of rational economic theory, it will have a very bad effect on rural industry through increased costs, and will also make the general cost of living in rural and provincial Queensland more expensive''.

That is what Mr Goss said. He is quoted as saying that, yet he still goes along and signs the agreement without any guarantee of what will happen. As Senator Chapman said earlier, Mr Goss has estimated that the increase in cost of living for Queenslanders could be anywhere between one per cent and 4 per cent. That is not good enough.

The Northern Territory Government got around this by agreeing to mirror all the non-charging aspects of the regulations implemented under the new scheme to achieve uniform regulations throughout Australia. Mr Goss has agreed to a system which comprises a nominal administration charge, a road use component of the Commonwealth diesel excise and a registration charge for vehicles which do not meet their road costs through fuel payments alone. Mr Goss should have taken the system's impact on regional Queensland into account before he signed the agreement. He obviously did not, whereas the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory was unwilling to sign until that impact was considered. The coalition has called consistently for an economic study into the impact of the proposed system on provincial and rural Australia, a call which equally as consistently has been ignored by the Government-but it does need to be done.

The invitation-only token talkfest thrown by Mr Snowdon, the ALP member for the Northern Territory, at the Alice Springs Sheraton last year, to which almost exclusively Canberra bureaucrats and Labor politicians were invited-it cost over $500 a head to get there-is no substitute for the detailed research which still needs to be done. In principle, the coalition supports the concept that road pricing should be done on a more rational basis; however, we do not think this Bill is fair.

Over the last year I have travelled extensively throughout north Queensland and have participated in numerous public meetings with transport operators, all of whom have been very concerned about what these charges might bring. Not surprisingly, while the shadow Minister for land transport, Mr David Hawker, has come to listen to their concerns, the Government Minister has refused to front the crowds.

Labor Party members have plenty of time to swan around in the Sheraton Hotel in Alice Springs at their pricey and exclusive talkfest, chatting amongst themselves and with their bureaucrats, but they do not seem to have any time to get out and talk to the transport operators on the ground and listen to their concerns. Unless the Government can face up to the responsibilities and assess the damage that the new system might cause to people living in remote areas, it should shelve this part of the legislation at this time.

In addition, it seems that the new charging system disadvantages individual and smaller transport operators, in comparison to the major transport companies which might be in a better position to absorb and survive registration and excise hikes. The more cynical of us might surmise about conspiracy theories and wonder whether Bob Hawke's mate and confidante at secret ALP leadership meetings gives him any special advantage when he wears his other hat as boss of one of Australia's transport giants.

A very common concern which is expressed to me often by operators is that they may be intentionally squeezed out of the system, leaving only the very large road freight companies, which will be able to accommodate the charge increase because of the smaller amount of competition once the small players are gone. If this does occur, the remaining carriers will be under less pressure to keep their prices down.

The Government, and now the Democrats, says that trucks do not pay enough, but there is a body of evidence which shows that a typical owner-driver pays 33 per cent of his revenue in one form of tax or another.

TALK.START.PARA: —At least.

—`At least', as my colleague says. If all the money that they paid were directed to roads-remembering the billions of dollars that are paid out in road transport all around Australia-we would not have to worry about our roads at all; they would be beautiful highways and we probably would be able to let motor vehicles on the roads without any registration.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite all the hyperbole of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and Mr Goss, it is interesting that in his industry statement earlier this year road transport was the only input to manufacturing that was denied special sales tax treatment. All the sales tax on road transport has remained, which is something that will not happen, I add, under the coalition's plan to abolish the wholesale sales tax completely, to cut income tax and to exempt all business inputs from that tax.

It is said that the road transport system does not pay its way, but it most certainly does. That point has never been understood by the Government and it is certainly not understood by the Democrats. The Democrats are announcing in their alternative Budget that they will collect an extra 1c per tonne per kilometre from all domestic road freight movements in Australia. They estimate that they will collect $855m in a year. If one does the arithmetic, that is an extra $50 in road freight tax from every man, woman and child in Australia. That is what the Democrats propose; that is what they think about people who live in remote Australia.

I can understand why Senator Kernot, who lives right in the centre of Brisbane, does not care two hoots about that sort of thing because one does not have to spend much in road freight when one lives in the centre of Brisbane. But if a person lives in the bush or in the more remote areas of Australia then the sorts of policies which the Democrats are proposing are an absolute anathema.

The Government has no place adding more taxes to reduce the competitive position in road transport. The Government should be using more of its existing fuel taxes on roads. You will recall, Mr Acting Deputy President, that before the last election the coalition promised to use an extra 2c per litre from the existing fuel taxes to fund the much needed improvements to our roads around Australia. What did the Government do? In real terms, the amount of money that has gone from fuel taxes back into roads has dropped by some 27 per cent under this Government, while the money collected from the fuel tax has gone up by some 90 per cent. So much for the Government showing its concern for roads and road funding.

Up my way we have a Labor member for the electorate of Herbert-for a little while anyhow. He is constantly arguing with his State Labor colleagues about who is at fault for the shocking state of the roads around Townsville and Cairns. He keeps getting publicity in the newspaper by telling the State Labor Government that it is not doing enough. Of course, the State Labor Government comes back and blames the Federal Government. So while we all rattle around on atrocious and very unsafe roads in north Queensland, we have the Labor Party in its State and Federal capacities at each other's throats blaming each other. It would be helpful if the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) and the State members who represent the north Queensland electorates got together and demanded a bit more of Queensland's share of the funds for the roads that do need repair and attention in north Queensland.

As I have mentioned, we welcome the Government's long overdue decision on B-doubles. We hope that the Government will do all that it can to ensure that the efficiency gains which this mode of transport offers are not hindered in any way. We support this part of the legislation, even though it has taken six years to come into this place. The Government should have acted long ago to ensure this major improvement to micro-economic reform, particularly in the land transport area. It is unfortunate that at the same time as it brings in this good legislation to allow for B-doubles, the Government then also wants to charge the hell out of these new trucks and rip more money in taxes from them. It is for this reason that we are not prepared to support the charging aspects of these Bills and our amendment addresses that discrepancy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill 1991 and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill 1991 which are before the chamber today are quite important because they create a framework in which B-doubles can be registered under the Federal interstate registration scheme. But there is a sting; because while the Government says, `You can register B-doubles', what it does with the other Bill is say, `We are going to impose a higher and discriminatory registration charge on B-doubles'. Of course, the only reason why a transport operator-be he a little transport operator or a big transport operator-will go to the greater cost of investing in a B-double is that he believes he will get greater efficiency out of it.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been shown that B-doubles give something like 20 per cent greater efficiency than ordinary articulated vehicles. But the problem is that, under this Government and under the two Bills that it has introduced in the Parliament today, the benefits of that greater efficiency do not go to the truckie, who has forked out of his own pocket to invest in more expensive equipment; instead, the benefits of the greater efficiency go to the Government. The Government is putting B-doubles on the road but taxing them off the road at the same time. Whilst we support and are fully behind the proposal for B-doubles to get Federal interstate road registration, we are totally opposed to the idea that this Federal Government should discriminate against those transport operators who wish to improve the efficiency of this nation's transport network.

Of course, this all comes under the framework of what the Australian Labor Party calls micro-economic reform. But where is the reform if, instead of reducing the cost of road transport and the input costs of road transport operators, those costs are merely made higher? There is no reform at all. It is a sham and it is a sham that will cause truckies and the people who put their freight on the roads to pay dearly. That is why we on this side of the chamber will not support the proposal by the Federal Government to put a higher registration charge on B-doubles than it puts on any other articulated vehicle on the roads. We say that that is wrong and is taking the benefits away from the truckie who deserves them and putting them in the coffers of the Federal Government in Canberra.

It is interesting that these Bills should come before the chamber at a time when Senator Gareth Evans is the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate, because on 14 July 1988, when Senator Evans was the Minister for Transport and Communications, he issued a press release after the Yass blockade. Paragraph 5 of that press release says:

the Government will retain the principles included in the existing legislation that the Federal registration charges are determined on the basis of road damage and that the practice of including limits on the level of charges in the legislation will be continued.
Two promises in one paragraph have been broken by these Bills that have been introduced into the Senate. We say that that is thoroughly unacceptable. It happens to B-doubles today.

Goodness help the Australian transport industry if Senator Evans ever becomes the Leader of the Government in the Senate. He has been Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate this week and already the Government has attacked B-doubles. Goodness help us if he ever becomes leader, because every truckie in this country will fall under the same high taxing regime that is shown in the second Bill.
Of course, the bottom line on all these proposals is really quite simple: this Federal Government is busy taxing the life out of small business.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about the consumption tax on the tourist industry.
—I will talk about the consumption tax. I thank Senator Bolkus for the interjection. I was going to go for five minutes, but I will now go a little longer.

SPEECH.PARA: This Federal Government will tax the life out of small business. Truckies are a perfect example of the most efficient sector of small business in this country. In the last 20 or 30 years, road transport charges have risen nowhere near the rate of increase in cost for the equipment that truckies use, yet truckies still manage, through the dead of night, to get the produce to the cities and get the goods from the cities to the towns. That is why I say that truckies are some of the hardest working people in this country. Unfortunately, the poor owner operator does not now get the profits of his labour; this is because of all the taxes that a truckie pays. Let us list them: sales tax of 20 per cent, fuel tax, provisional tax, registration charges and, if he is lucky enough to make a profit, income tax.

If we put all those taxes to one side of the equation and put the small bit of money that he takes home to his wife and kids at the end of the week to the other side, everybody can see who gets the majority of the profits of the road transport operator-it is not the road transport operator but the Federal Government, the people sitting on the other side of the chamber. We find that wholly unacceptable and inequitable.

Minister Bolkus challenged me to talk about the goods and services tax. I am glad he did. It was only about a month ago that I heard the Labor Party's State Treasurer in Queensland saying on ABC radio that this goods and services tax would be absolutely terrible because it would introduce a 15 per cent tax on road transport. But like his Federal colleagues, he did not have the honesty and integrity to say that they are already imposing a 20 per cent sales tax on road transport--

TALK.START.PARA: —And business inputs will be free.

—Exactly. He did not say that the coalition's proposal for a goods and services tax will free small and large business-every business in this country-for the first time ever from this evil government tax on their input costs. The State Labor Party Treasurer in Queensland did not have the honesty or the integrity to tell the people listening to that program that not only is there a 20 per cent tax on the transport but also there is a 20 per cent tax on the input costs of those truckies. For many small operators, that 20 per cent tax means the difference between survival and going under.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very proud to talk about the goods and services tax and our proposal to abolish the wholesale sales tax lock stock and barrel. This Government does not have the honesty to do it; it does not have the honesty to talk about what it is doing to the road transport operators; and it does not have the courage or commitment to real reform to bring about a reduction in cost for businesses in this country. We in the National Party are right behind road transport operators all the way because we recognise the important contribution that they make to maintaining the living standards of people in country areas.

To anybody who wishes to examine this debate more carefully, I can only commend to them the speech given earlier today by Senator Tambling, the Deputy Leader of the National Party in the Senate, who hit it on the head when he said that these proposals, which are the forerunner of the federal interstate road registration scheme that was proposed at the Special Premiers Conference, are a complete volte-face from all the fine rhetoric that we heard from the Labor Party in Alice Springs and from what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said in his so-called famous speech of 1989. They are a complete volte-face from everything that Senator Evans spoke about in 1988. They show that the people who sit on the other side of the chamber cannot be trusted to look after small business, cannot be trusted to look after the road transport operator and cannot be trusted with the future of this nation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 3 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister seen a report by F Dominic Fanning, of June 1990, entitled Koalas in south eastern New South Wales, in which the establishment of a koala research zone in the Mt Darragh area is recommended.
(2) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a report in the Canberra Times of 30 April 1991 that a koala was sighted on 20 April 1991 in the research zone.
(3) Can the Minister say whether there is logging being carried out in the research zone; if so, is it on private land or in state forest.

(4) In view of the koala sighting mentioned in (2), will the Minister, as a matter of urgency, invoke the powers under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 to have the logging stopped, and to review the Harris-Daishowa woodchip export licence; if not why not.
(5) Will the Minister consult urgently with the Minister for the Environment in NSW with a view to having the Mt Darragh region declared a fauna protection area.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (3) The New South Wales (NSW) Minister for Forests, Mr West, has stated that logging will not be carried out on Crown Land including state forests which has been identified as koala habitat, including areas within the research zones, until further investigations have determined the base range of the animals in that vicinity. Logging which is carried out on private land is generally carried out by private sawmillers and is not subject to State Government regulation unless the area is within a protected zone for soil and water conservation requirements. There have been reports of logging on private land in the vicinity of Mt Darragh.

(4) Any review of the Harris-Daishowa export licence is a matter for the Minister for Resources. Neither the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 nor the Administrative Procedures under the Act provide the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories with any power to have logging in the south east forests (or elsewhere) stopped. The Administrative Procedures, however, provide for a review and assessment of the environmental aspects, including in particular the effectiveness of any safeguards or standards adopted or applied for the protection of the environment, of a proposed action which has previously been the subject of action under the Act. The export of woodchips by Harris- Daishowa for the period 1990-2010, including chips sourced from the south east forests, was the subject of an assessment under the Act during 1986-1988.

There has been considerable correspondence on this issue between myself and Mr West in order to determine the actions of the New South Wales management agencies in light of the growing evidence that the south east forests are koala habitat. I have recently written to Mr West again to satisfy myself that all necessary measures will be and are being undertaken to protect the koala habitat in this forest. The information obtained from this correspondence will allow me to properly consider the need for a review under the provisions of the Administrative Procedures under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974.

(5) The koala management plan for the south east forests of NSW is a joint initiative of the NSW Forestry Commission and the NSW National Parks and Wildlife Service. I have also again raised with Mr West what effect the sighting of koalas and the required management will have on the proposed boundaries for the National Parks agreed to as part of the Agreement on the south east forests between the NSW and Commonwealth Governments last year.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: World Heritage Listing of Wet Tropics Area

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 17 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When the Government nominated the Wet Tropics of north Queensland for World Heritage Listing, what, if any, provisions were made to compensate those adversely affected by the listing but not directly involved in the timber industry.
(2) Were the tin mining operations of Stannum Pty Ltd adversely affected by the World Heritage Listing of their China Camp Tin Leases.

(3) In March 1988, did the then Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson), tell the directors of the mining company, Stannum Pty Ltd, that even though the company did not meet guidelines for compensation from the World Heritage Listing Structural Adjustment Package, he was prepared to give the company's case for compensation further consideration.
(4) Did the then Minister seek the views of the Interim Management Authority of the Wet Tropics of Queensland as he committed himself to doing in his letter of 28 November 1989 to Stannum Pty Ltd.
(5) If the Authority's view was actually sought, what were its recommendations to the Minister.

(6) Did the then Minister ask Price Waterhouse &Co. to prepare an independent report on Stannum Pty Ltd's claim for compensation in relation to the effect on the company's mining operations of the World Heritage Listing of the Wet Tropics, as he committed himself to doing in his letter of 28 November 1989 to Stannum Pty Ltd; if so, what were its findings in relation to Stannum's compensation claim.

(7) Why is it that no formal rejection or acceptance of Stannum's application for assistance was ever forwarded to the company until May 1990, when the new Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) did so.
(8) On what grounds did the Minister eventually dismiss Stannum Pty Ltd's claim for compensation.

(9) Does the Minister believe it acceptable to dismiss the compensation claim made by Stannum Pty Ltd on the grounds that the company was ineligible for Structural Adjustment Package assistance, not being directly associated with logging, as is indicated by the Parliamentary Secretary in a letter of 21 September 1990.
(10) What course of action does the Minister now recommend to Stannum Pty Ltd, in relation to their China Camp Leases.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No provisions were made to compensate interests not directly involved with rainforest logging in the Wet Tropics of Queensland World Heritage Area.

(2) Stannum Pty Ltd was not mining or processing tin at China Camp in December 1987, the date of nomination of the Wet Tropics of Queensland for World Heritage listing or in December 1988, the date of listing of the area.

(3) No. However, the then Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, did write to the Directors of Stannum Pty Ltd on 9 March 1989 regarding the China Camp area in the following terms:

`The Government has provided a $75m Structural Adjustment Package to assist workers and businesses affected by the cessation of logging. Your case therefore does not meet the guidelines for compensation under that package.

I am prepared to give your case for compensation further consideration. However I would prefer to consider revised proposals from you, either for mining of the leases by low impact methods or for other environmentally acceptable uses of the land . . .'

(4) and (5) The then Minister's Department informally advised the Chairman of the Interim Management Authority in December 1989 that Stannum Pty Ltd's mining and compensation proposals would be referred to the Authority for advice. However, before this matter was formally referred, negotiations commenced with the Queensland Government on establishing new joint Commonwealth/State management arrangements.

(6) In accordance with the undertaking given in the then Minister's letter to Stannum Pty Ltd of 28 November 1989, the then Minister's Department wrote to Price Waterhouse, Canberra on 1 December 1989 requesting advice on the compensation claim from Stannum Pty Ltd. Following a detailed examination of company records in Perth and an inspection of the China Camp site, Price Waterhouse advised that the basis of the claim was inappropriate.

(7) and (8) Between March 1989 and April 1990 a number of letters was exchanged between the Commonwealth, Cultus Gold N.L. (of which Stannum was a wholly owned subsidiary) and Stannum Pty Ltd on the issue of the leases, including in particular the issue of revised proposals for the leases, either for the mining of the leases by low impact methods or for other environmentally acceptable uses of the land.
Stannum was advised by me in May 1990 in the following terms:

`I understand that you have no new proposals for environmentally compatible uses of your leases. Regretfully I cannot permit your proposed mining activities to proceed to the detriment of the World Heritage values of the Wet Tropics.'
`. . . It is not Commonwealth policy to compensate mining companies where their activities are found to be incompatible with Australia's natural or cultural heritage.'

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, upon notice, on 8 July 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: Considering: (a) s.18(1) of the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 governing the provisions of Federal Government funding to the States for higher education institutions which states `the State will ensure that each institution situated in the State does not charge any student fees in respect of that year or a part of that year except as provided by s.13'; and (b) the definition of fees in s.3 of the Act:

(1) Has the Minister made notification under paragraph (g) of s.3 of the Act in respect of those fees that are currently being levied by the University of Wollongong and other tertiary institutions which include late withdrawal fees, examination reassessment fees, failure to enrol by prescribed date and late enrolment fee charges; if not, what action will be taken with regard to these breaches of the funding provisions of the Higher Education Funding Act 1988.

(2) If those institutions levying fees under s.3 paragraphs (a) to (h) have in fact contravened the conditions under which the States receive funding from the Commonwealth, what action, if any, will the Minister be taking regarding such contraventions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) It is a condition of grants to the States under the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 that the States ensure that institutions do not charge any student fees except as provided by s.13. S.3 of the Act defines `fees' for this purpose. The Minister may issue a notification under paragraph (g) of s.3 of the Act in cases where a specific charge falls within that definition of fees.

In the case of charges that are not fees as defined, the question of notification does not arise. Charges for materials or services which are not compulsory to undertaking a course are not `fees' under the Act, nor are charges in the nature of a fine or penalty. The Department of Employment, Education and Training has written to institutions to inform them of the principles that determine whether or not particular charges might constitute `fees' under the Act.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 8 July 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the prescription drug, Marvelon described as the leading contraceptive pill worldwide:
(1) Why has Marvelon been prevented from being sold in Australia.
(2) How many times has Marvelon been before the Drug Advisory Committee and on what dates.
(3) What is the reason on every occasion why Marvelon has not been approved.
(4) What is the most widely sold contraceptive in Australia.
(5) What are the names of the companies that can sell contraceptive pills in Australia.
(6) Why have no new contraceptive hormone pills been made available in Australia since 1981.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The sponsor company, Organon, has failed to satisfy Australian Drug Evaluation Committee's (ADEC) concerns over the quality, safety and efficacy of the product Marvelon.
(2) The product Marvelon has been considered by ADEC twice. The first occasion was in April 1989. An appeal against the April decision was heard by ADEC in December 1989.

(3) The exact reasons for rejection would be considered commercially confidential by the sponsor company. They relate to inadequate evidence of the rate and extent of absorption of active ingredients and inadequate animal toxicity studies. No clinical evidence for a comparative advantage for the use of Marvelon over currently available products was available, but there was some evidence of increased problems with cycle control in women using Marvelon. There was insufficient clinical benefit to outweigh other defects.
(4) The most widely prescribed oral contraceptive on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) is Triphasil/Triquilar (levonorgestrel with ethinyloestradiol--

(6) The reasons why a particular product has not been made available in Australia are varied. They relate to failure by sponsor companies to lodge an application, in many cases based on commercial decisions made by the sponsors after assessing the marketing supply and demand situation, lack of development of innovative products and use of alternate contraceptive techniques in preference to drug products.

(b) As mentioned in (a) above, the Plan of Management made available for public comment in June 1991 will apply to the enlarged Kakadu National Park. (i) As noted above, the Plan of Management has been made available for public comment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 26 July 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What role has Australia played in discussions on arms transparencies and an arms register at the United Nations.
(2) How long have these discussions been going on.
(3) Would such a register include a record of all military equipment imports and exports in and out of Australia, both lethal and non-lethal; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian expert, Dr Ron Huisken, has been active and influential in the deliberations of the UN Expert Group on Conventional Arms Transfers. In particular, Australia was responsible for an important redraft of the 9th chapter of the Group's report, which contains the conclusions and recommendations of the Group, including the recommendation for the establishment of a UN arms transfer register.

(2) There have been four meetings of the Expert Group since it was established, pursuant to UN Resolution 44/75 I, in 1988. This resolution requested the Secretary General, with the assistance of government experts to explore ways and means of promoting transparency in the international transfer of conventional arms on a universal and non-discriminatory basis.
The conclusions and recommendations of the Group are to be submitted to the General Assembly at its 46th session which will begin on 17 September this year.

(3) In accordance with its mandate, the Expert Group's recommendations cover only conventional arms transfers; and do not attempt to define specific categories of arms to be included in the register. The Group has recommended to the Secretary General that a second Expert Group be mandated to define the scope and parameters of the equipment that be included in the register.

The detail of the arrangements for reporting sales and imports also remains to be established. Australia will continue actively to support the early establishment of a working UN register, and we will continue to contribute positively to its development.
